reviewText:
So, as a lover of Train simulator from Microsoft; I went ahead and purchased this game....well I can't really say that it is a bad purchase, but it is not a good one either.

It is true that I didn't play 100 hours or so; but if I was able to spot the issues after few hours, either I am really attentive (maybe because I used to work as QA?), or for most, these issues are not really issues that can be considered a deal breaker.

As is, the game is worth probably not more than 10-15 USD.

Let's clarify more in details, so you can have an idea.

Overall the menu is clean; the options thou are quite confusing, so it will take you a bit to understand how can you make a new route or check which add-on you have. there is a quick drive option, which will be useful to give you an idea of the game, and also some tutorials that explains you the controls.

All right IF you can survive the hate against the in game purchase screen....the game won't leave you be if you change train or track in the free roaming mode, pushing you to buy more.

The graphic is OK; overall it feels like a bit antiquated at times, but it is clean and overall does its job. There are some issues with the textures, where they flicker (especially if you are on maps that has water; you can see flickering where the water meets the land, but there are various instances all over the game); but overall the game is not showing tremendous corruption.
The train itself are made quite nicely; lots of details on the outside; inside they are so-so, with some good textures but overall very simplicistic and not super detailed. Considering that they are the main point of the game, I would expect something similar to other products in the simulation realm  (like airplane or car simulators; just to mention few...this is a simulator after all, so it has to be compared to other sims).
The object on the side of the route are many and well done; not super but they do their good immersion job.

The arrangement of the objects and scenery thou may vary from map to map...some are quite stunning, with light effects and awesome arrangement; while others (like the mountain maps with snow), are so dull and bland.
Also you can see in the distance the issue with object placements, where tree just disappear, and you see basically the area that goes from tree populated, to bald.

The human 3d models are quite atrocious: their animations are approximate, there is very little variation among the meshes and textures, and also the collision and AI is quite disappointing....at times they just go for a spin, walking around the same spot like a dog running behind its tail. This is more evident if you just sit in a station and set the external camera. After a bit they just go trough scenery items, or start to act totally weird.

The cars are OK; after all you don't have to have many different ones, since you rarely see them, but at the crossing they are there, and you can see that the variation is limited to 2-3 types. Also their collision with the ground is uneven...in some maps you see them sinking in the ground plane....

The engine seems to work decently, but using high speed trains, you can see the framerate getting choppy (2x8 core processors, Radeon 5870, which is able to run more demanding games with impeccable performances); it feels like the engine is not that optimized, or maybe is based on old technology (I didn't follow the whole story of the company honestly, I just know that they are around since quite some time). At times feels like an indie game made with these free SDK like Unity or UDK, instead than a dedicated engine (nothing wrong with indie SDK; but you need to know your limitations).

But I can live with these issues in the end, altho the main problems are on the central gameplay itself.

You are basically a conductor (engineer), and the main point is the career, where you go trough scenery after scenery, which has different tracks and trains, and get rated based on your performace on 3 categories :
- comfort of passengers (basically how good you are with accelerating and breaking)
- Speed limits compliance
- time table compliance

The idea is fabulous; but the implementation is full of issues.

I tried few scenarios, and there is an underlying problem with speed: there is a screen that show you where the speed limits are, so you can act accordingly and set the train to the right speed. Once you pass the limit by 1 MPH, you get the alert of speeding and you start to loose points.
This is where the issues start.

The first problem is that the limit does not allow you any kind of room to fail....either you time perfectly your brake and acceleration, or you start to slow down too early, which makes you loose time (which reflects on the time table compliance; since the schedule is quite tight ). No room for errors, which is unrealistic (isn't this a sim?)

Any person that drive a train knows, that you are allowed to exceed the limits to stay on schedule, by a certain percentage; while here the developers decided to set it to 1 MPH. Now the justification is it is to make it harder and more realistic"; while the truth is that is easier to just set things in this way
date: instead than work around a flexible way to allow speeding; and give different kind of penalty to players.\n\nThe second issue is due to the incorrect sync of the speed limit between the map and the main view. You are nicely riding
hoursPlayed: see the signal and prepare to slow down...and then out of the blue
voteText: the limit change and you find yourself speeding when you are few miles away from the signal.\nThis happened to me almost in any scenario that I tried so far; basically the map that you see on your display
helpfulPercent: is not synced with the track
votesHelpful: giving you incorrect data. Playing like that is like to drive a submarine with an elementary school map not in scale.\n\nYou will loose a ton of points
votesTotal: get frustrated and overall
votesFunny: end up not enjoying the game.\nIn one instance; I had a limit of something like 225 KPH
commentsCount: I was at 190 KPH
column16: then at one point
column17: while approaching a station (after playing for 30 minutes or so); the limit changed out of the blue
column18: and the train engaged the emergency alarm. I ended up being stopped in a tunnel
column19: 2 miles away from the station
column20: and no chance to have the train to restart (the alarm was on; even after resetting the alarm
column21: it would not allow me to move the train no matter what). I had to restart the mission and throw a couple of things from my desk on the wall
column22: for the frustration. Nobody mentioned that you need to put in neutral
column23: then pull the brake control all the way back
column24: then start again...not even the manual.\n\nThen let's talk about the content itself: the base game is limited to few tracks; so if you want a career
column25: you need to buy DLC (20-40 USD a pop). Which is absurd

after spending money for the main game. Imagine Final fantasy where after the first mission ask you to go buy the DLC to continue the game.

reviewText:
Train Simulator 2014 is the first game ever that made me test the [sadly non existent] Steam refund policy. I still can't believe I spent over $50 on this totally crappy game. I played it for barely 3 hours before I realized I will never want to play this game again and uninstalled it.

The base game has very little content out of the box and DLCs cost so much I thought it was some sort of a glitch with Steam at first, then reading the forums I realized it is how the routes and train model are priced. I still can't believe they are seriously trying to charge $20-$40 for a route or train model.

The game comes with no tutorials to speak of. There are supposed to be tutorials in the game and they do appear in the list of in game tutorials but trying to run them gives some cryptic error. I had to dig through the forums to figure out that these tutorials are leftovers from previous versions of the game and require some DLC (which of course, I will never buy).

The game crashes too often. By today's standards, It doesn't look all that great graphically. The User Interface feels like it was designed by a fresh year student as a home project. There isn't much content and overall, the game is pretty boring.

Maybe total die hard train simulator fans have no choice but to buy this game but for anyone like me, who just wanted to play with trains, this game isn't worth it.

Stay away.

reviewText:
Are you sitting comfortably - then I'll begin.

Once upon a time back in September 2007 Kuju and Railsimulator.com made their introduction to the scene of Rail Simulators, and at that time, both Microsoft and Trainz had, or were in the process of, folding.

At this time, Railsimulator.com, driven by Messers Siddell and Lucas, were a very approachable company, and quite frankly, they lifted up this game 100% in the first 4-5 years.

Then, in marched Mr Jackson, an ex Manager from EA and also a supposed Railfan. Alarm bells rang with me then, but I gave them the benefit of the doubt, and I persisted with this game through to 2015, even though the company, by now called Dovetail, had effectively closed off any sort of communication with themselves, were selling, selling, selling - but made no visible effort to correct any of the major bugs now being sold to us.

As someone else here said, while it can satisfy the rail fans wish of driving a train (at least virtually), it doesn't do it very well. A plethora of never to be fixed bugs, a greedy development team and addons which are overpriced, fluctuate in quality and usually have some part (such as sounds) either recycled from older addons or completely inaccurate. I've played this game for about 8 years now and while it looks visually like its improved, its actually gotten worse.

The only thing that saves this game is the third party developers that create far better addons as well as offer better service, especially Thompson.

So if you buy this, please bear these points in mind, and make your own mind up about the truth of it all. I will be buying this for myself, but am pretty sure this will be the final year, unless they pull their socks up, and realise that any successful company ALSO needs Customer Support.

ADDENDUM
Just found out the reason for all the hype whilst not telling us too much - that is because it will cost UK users £99.99!! ($150, or 120euros approx!!) This means I am gone, as no way I'm going to fork that out in one lump, and going by recent Twitch reveiws, what do you get for it - Stevens Pass (which I actually wanted), a China Clay pit and an olden times" Dawlish Riviera - otherwise the game is the same as we have already. For that price
date: I would want a real engine to drive. :)"

Played Euro Truck Simulator? Great isn't it? Made by a reputable company renowned for rewarding its loyal fanbase with superbly crafted, highly polished games. And all delivered at reasonable prices too.

reviewText:
At first I enjoyed this game but am now getting annoyed by the serious amount of bugs that keep cropping up every time I play, eg:

1) Randomly forgetting which missions I've cleared in career mode
2) Penalising me after hiding upcoming speed-limit changes and slamming on the emergency brakes when going through a warning light instead of easing off the accelerator like it's supposed to
3) Not re-loading mission-critical resources when retrying scenarios etc etc

Also, considering I've got a fairly decent gaming set-up, I have to turn the graphic levels way down otherwise I get very choppy framerates, and the graphics aren't exactly on the level of Crysis so this game really needs updates.

It's a shame as it does have potential. I would have expected a fair bit more for the price as well, maybe 2-3 more routes. The DLC is all horribly overpriced too, it would have to drop by at least 60-70% before I'd consider buying any of it, and that's only if they fix the bugs first!

UPDATE 15/11/14: Tried the game again after a recent update (the first one for ages), hoping to see a few bugs fixed. Instead, all the developers seem to have done is remove the notification when you are being penalised, which (conveniently for them) covers-up some of the aforementioned bugs but doesn't actually fix any of them. Now, if I was cynical I might even say they've done it for that very reason, as it's obviously a lot easier and cheaper than actually employing somebody to properly fix the game, but I'm sure they'd never sink that low!

Also, strangely, they've changed the controller mapping to a more awkward configuration and it's no longer mapped to how it says on the configuration screen.

reviewText:
It's really hard to recommend this game. I've played it for several hours learning how to drive those trains, and found out how buggy this game can be.

First of all - I like simulations. I already own Truck Simulator and have had my fun with it. Train simulator is great deal different, but i still like the idea of driving these heavy machines. I also have patience to learn through trial and error, so with this in mind:
- A loco, having towed 20 cars doesn't have wheel slip, then all of a sudden, while towing 10 of them it HAS ENORMOUS wheel slip, so you have to apply ony 20-25% power and accelerate to 80kph, can't apply more power or wheel slip at e.g. 40kph. What's the deal with that? Sunny day, by the way.
- You know how side track view (the one at the bottom) shows speed limits, then all of a sudden one of them grows just in front of my train, there's no way I could have slowed down as not to cause my train to enter emergency-brake mode or incur a penalty.
- Red lights ocassionally show up right after a 90 degree turn with no indication beforehand. This is in one of these scenarios with intermodal train, Hamburg - Hanover route, fourth difficulty level.

Game loading speed is abysmal. My kettle boils water faster. I have decent PC, mind you, games are on 4x2TB Raid drive. Should be fast, right? Other games load fast. Lots of texture flickering on screen. Game looks like it had no anti-alias at all. And in 1080p resolution. Truck simulator has an option which can increase detail at distance if you had enough power. Here said distance is minimal, try changing FOV in order to observe distant train - it sometimes even appears half-way under ground, which is funny.... not.

And what the heck is it with all these route or loco DLCs carrying whole game price tag... I mean you can have fun with only these 3 routes provided... but not for long.

Anyway, wasted potential, for a simulator. The fact that I have bought it at Christmas Sale price saves it a bit though.

reviewText:
Train Simulator, an interesting game, for the most part it is a pretty good game but there are some definate flaws.

Positives
+ Lots of DLC which means a huge amount of content to play with.
+ Fairly easy to understand and get into
+ Steam workshop expands the playtime hugely

So what does it get wrong?
- This is not really a simulator since there is only about 5 buttons in the cab that work..
- Tile loading system. This means the game micro-freezes each time it loads a new tile.
- Sounds are often inaccurate and poor quality, and they copy and paste them from train to train.
- Way too many bugs that they won't fix.
- DLC is overpriced. Where do they get these prices from?
- They reskin a train, call it a new one and sell it for another £11.99..
- Graphics are OKAY in areas, but horrid in others.
- Level of quality is inconsistent.
- They force advertising of their next DLC down your throat any chance they get. On the menu, on the loading screen..

I vould go on for a while. It's a game that has a lot of potential, but the devs are too busy concentrating on treating their customers like cattle and chugging out new DLC rather than patching the game, and fixing existing DLC.

reviewText: So I finally got the pleasure of downloading the 1.4GB update to TS2016. I went to load my custom consist with SD70s on Union Pacific's Sherman Hill, one of my favourite routes. I haven't read into it enough to know whether or not this is supposed to be a beta, I hope it is because this new version is just awful. Instead of background music you only hear the continuous winter wind blowing on the menu screens from the introduction video. Exciting. There's no loading bar or screens to showcase recently released routes/trains as there was in the past, you get to stare at a black screen for several seconds/minutes and hope your desired route/scenario is still loading. The SD70 which was my favourite locomotive for being one of few with excellent audio, has been 'improved' to now sound nothing like a train. Rolling stock over the tracks sounds are even more terrible. On top of it all, the stupid brake decrease glitch - which I first discovered driving Soldier Summit's SD40-2 which requires you to spam the decrease button to shut the brakes off - has now also plagued my beloved SD70.\n\nThis is an embarrassment. reviewText:
This game...is...of debatable quality.

The Good Things
Being a hell of a rail-fan, this game has ways to deliever. The graphics are fairly good overall, but I think tweaks here and there are needed. In terms of controls, they are fairly realistic to my knowledge in terms of setup. The wheelslip is fairly accurate, as starting a train on a snowy hill side is a pain in the ♥♥♥ (as it should be).
Routes are fairly accurate in detail.

[h2]The Bad Things[/h2]

For starts, this game is spammed with DLC. And it isn't done correctly. I payed nearly twenty bucks for this thing when it was on a sale exceeding 50%. Given my tight as hell budget, that was pushing it. I hoped that it would be worth it. Wrong. For starts, you get maybe three different overall routes, about a total of a dozen senarios (not including tutorals),  a little over a half-dozen locomotives (half of which cannot be drived outside of Quick-Drive), and next to nothing in terms of passenger services. Freight, freight, frieght. Last time I checked, that was what it was like in most of the US. While I am from the US, I do wish to remind you that I live in Illinois, an area which sees a good amount of public transport being by train. And I know as far as Europe that it is practically a nessisaty.
So in order to get more content, I need to get DLC. And it isn't the $1.99 type of DLC either. I'm talking full price. If you want another route, more engines, freight, etc. and maybe 4-5 more scenarios, then expect to pay at least $20...more likely it will be above that. How many Steam engines come with this game? One. And it is in the stupid Academy paint scheme. It looks real dumb when you want to drive one, and the only way to do that is to play a quick drive and try to ignore all the electric and diesel trains that flash past you, making you look kinda stupid.
Now, with wheelslip. Is it something that people like? Hell no. But last time I checked, wheelslip is usually something that is out of a driver's control. I'm sorry I gotta start on a steep hill with a 50 car train; that light was red. But I don't think I should be forced to give next to no throttle and allow my train to slide down helplessly, or risk recieveing huge-♥♥♥ penalties.
Now I know you guys are not exactly aiming for a 100% realistic road simulator. I mean, that's kind of a given to me. But on the other hand, I don't think most railroad crossings have the lights going off well before the gates even go off. And I mean that your train is doing 30 miles an hour, up a steep hill, and still close to a mile from the crossing. Then on top of that, the middle of the train will still be crossing through when the gates will go up. I mean do you know how stupid it looks when that happens? And then lets have them drive through the train like it's a hologram.
The speed limit is kinda crazy. I think most people will go five over and not have much of a penalty. But when you are are triple-digit speeds, the tenth-of-a-mile in the speedometer goes away. And if you suddenly are going 121 miles an hour instead of 120, then say good-bye to your points. Also, a little hard for most trains to go down a steep as hell hill with a massive freight train, and manage to spend the entrie time at a slug-like pace of a mere 25 miles an hour. I'm sure more then one engineer have gotten bored with the sluggishness and went a little bit over on the straightaways to cut down some time. They aren't being reckless.
Derailments are horrible in terms of accuracy. I understand that you are not wanting to focus on such a thing, but face it; these things happen. That said, four railcars derailing should not make the entire 50-car train derail as well. That's kinda stupid.

It's a good game. It has potental. But poor physics, next to no content without paying hundreds of dollars, abnormally-strict rules, among other things make what could be a fantastic game into a mediocure-at-best pile of ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
This is a hard one.  I like trains, I like train simulators (OpenBVE being by far the best and is free) but Train Simulator 2014 (2012 when I bought it) is so...lacklustre.

Don't get me wrong, the visual detail ranges from adequate (ground textures, houses, cars) to impressively realised (stations, viaducts, overall scenery) however it is in how you drive the train which is very uninteractive.  I draw comparisons to OpenBVE because everything has a button and each diesel/electric train has throttle *positions* rather than a throttle that cannot be set to go at a certain percentage (and goes through the power level percentages extremely smoothly), the sounds recorded by amateurs for OpenBVE have the realism that Train Simuator lacks (trains sound like they are idling, even when the throttle is at 100% and going up a gradient) and if you care about the little details (such as replying to the guard's buzzer) then you're going to notice their conspicuous absence.

For the most part you will be sat there doing nothing, whereas in OpenBVE you would be constantly adjusting throttle and braking to ensure best possible speed, time and passenger comfort (should you be doing a passenger run) or taking into account how the freight changes the handling.  This is the kind of pressure that's present in Euro Truck Simulator (which is disappointing on a different level, but not in terms of the actual driving of the trucks) but not here in Train Simulator 2014.

I even bought the Settle-Carlisle pack during the sale, just to see if the experience would be any different to those included as standard.  The answer, rather resoundingly, is no as the trains still sound awful (the horns may as well be weak synth or foleyed car horns, the steam engine noises are equally weak), the amount of interactivity is negligible and when there is pressure on the more difficult routes? Be prepared for awful controls and trains that need to go to their virtual depot for either scrapping or rebuilding from scratch as they are that poor in terms of performance.

I would have loved to have said that Train Simulator was - at least - good.  But it isn't.  Until Train Simulator receives a thorough reworking, it is best that you avoid this and either go buy a train set; play OpenBVE/Transport Tycoon or volunteer at your local heritage railway.  You'll save a lot of money (especially where all the DLC combined costs over £1000 prior to a Steam sale) and you'll have a far more enriching experience.

reviewText: Buggy game, requires paid DLC for it to be fun. I can't run the tutorials because they simply won't load, and half the time the game either crashes or the menu doesn't load properly. Really disappointed, it had so much potential. When games like Euro Truck Simulator can create a similar experience with free-roaming trucks in Europe, I don't see why a train game would have to cost 100x more.

reviewText: Bought this on sale for the Christmas Holiday Train. Ridiculously buggy, graphical glitches, and system dump files abound. The Christmas DLC is a very lacking one-room track populated with ugly textures (circa 1990s gamebuilders), questionable inclusion of scene assets (outdoors/stairs/doors/hallways in world editor), and overall poor optimisation and execution. Had originally decided to try this to see if it would be a suitable holiday steam gift for friends... big resounding 'NO' on that. Game control layout is terribly though-out and the UI is not intuitive. This christmas sale seems to be a marketing ploy to push TS2014 and hope users buy ridiculously over-priced DLC content to expand a virtually empty content game engine. Stay away like the plague.

reviewText:
It's OK(ish). However - The graphics and believability for the scenery and environment are quite poor (Looks too legoish and repetitive). The add-on's are way, way overpriced. £12 - £17 for 1 Loco to run up and down the same line that you're now getting bored with is absolute extortion.

Worse still - It doesn’t come with many routes. So you will be looking at spending around £25 per route, once you have completed all the scenarios for the few existing routes that you got with the game.

You can download free stuff from steam for this game e.g. routes, scenarios etc, but be warned - You will find that you still need to buy more routes and add-on packs to actually play them and make them work.

I downloaded the 56xx GWR Steam Loco add on for this game in loving memory of my Dad who always wanted to drive a steam train (I thought I'd complete his ambition for him). When I went to the tutorial list for this class of loco - I found that I could not play any of the scenarios or use the tutorial because I don't have the Memories Of Maerdy" route add on priced at £17.99

What's also annoying for me is not all of the listed scenarios in this game are playable using the loco's that you already have with the original game. If you attempt to play one - You just get greeted with an in game pop-up advising you that you need to purchase yet another route to play this scenario.

It's full of bugs too - e.g. people walking across the track at a stations

reviewText:
I have played hundreds of hours with all the iterations of Train Simulator for years. This newest version, TS2014, is at best buggy and unoptimized and at worst unplayable.  Bugs have existed in this game for years w/o fix.  Problems with scenarios and routes have been reported time and time again, yet no fix, years after release (I'm looking at you Northeast Corridor).

DLC is very overpriced.  $40 for routes and $20 for rolling stock?  More reasonable would be $20 for routes and $10 for rolling stock.

While I have enjoyed this game in the past, I cannot recommend it now.  My only hope for this game is that another company will buy the current owners and start from scratch.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
TS2015 Edit: Game is a bit more optimized now and runs a little better on high end machines. However the years old bugs still exist and the DLC is still way overpriced. Still would not recommend.

Let's start complimenting theese guys on making a visually good game. By visually good, I say it by making textures for dirty windows, rain drops on the windows, and other enviromental stuff, but, the textures on both interior and exteriors aren't that much good looking, as on a resolution of 1366x768 I can't read some of the things written in the cab controls. About controls, they have support for a controller, but you can't customize the controls, and what about the conductor to help you out?

Another down side of this game is the missions, with and EXTREMELY short timetable. A second more or less to press the load/unload command and you're already late and loosing points, not to say that you have to figure out the exact distance to start braking from the speed limit to stop wit the entire train on the station, toherwise you're loosing points too. Physics? they have some good things but bad things, but I'd say they still have some work to do.

What about the IMMENSE number os DLC's? they throw you off from playing this game, they give you a loco on the tutorial that ISN'T EVEN AVAILABLE TO PLAY!, what the heck are you doing people? Still, work to polish your engine, I'm running it on a decent and considered high end machine and it lags, that shouldn't be happening IMO.

This is my first review on a game, and it's a negative one. I gave you a chance on this, and I'm not happy with it, you lost a possible client. For everyone else up to buy it, get it on a heavy discount, it's not worth it unless it's 75% off or more, maybe don't even buy it, save for something better

reviewText:
I have had a love for trains since I was a child and own a few different versions of Train Simulator, along with other train games, but I have to say, I am a bit annoyed at the design of this current game. I am the type of person to explore and then create my own world with these games, but I was a bit shocked at the way the current game operates. The graphics and sound, scenarios, and overall gameplay is fine, but do I need to see advertisements when loading, do I need to have scenarios show up and then tell me to buy them? Sure, its fine to promote DLC, but do it in a sub menu or somewhere else. I feel like I purchased advertisment spam more than a game.

Now comes editing. Seriously need to rework the key bindings here and make it a default for zoom to the mouse scroll. Arrow keys vs. the WASD common movement assignments? REALLY! I'm sorry, but honestly I can't see myself enjoying this version over previous ones. I hope my opinion changes as I play, but first impressions leave it a bit low...

reviewText: First of all, please note I would only recommend to an avid train enthusiast but not to an individual that knows nothing about trains. The base game itself is quite positive for those looking to have a realistic driving experience (3rd or 1st person), but the reason i advise non-train buffs to not purchase it is because of the amount of facts and figures you will come across and the fact that if you are not into it, then the DLCs are useless. The total DLC cost is well over a £3000 which makes it an incredibly over-priced game for what it is; a simulator. For £3000 you could buy a real train. Although, being an enthusiast myself, it is excellent to have a wide range of locomotives, routes and skin packs to be able to customize your fleet. A real con is where they sell you a train for £11.99 and call it new even though it has only been re-skined. Of course you do not have to buy every single DLC, but for instance I have spent over £150 on DLCs alone, way too much for a simulator. A good feature of this game is the create your own route feature. This is very complex but once you have learnt the basics, an excellent way to plan out a model railway. There are also modes such as free-roam (self-explanatory), scenario based, career scenario based and quick drive. Quick drive was added in quite a recent update and is one of my preferred modes; you are able to select any locomotive on any route, setting the time and day etc... Comparibly the scenarioes are excellent and with the addition of the workshop are seemingly endless. Overall, not a great game but don't allow the 200 and something hours tell you otherwise; please note, this was a big waste of my life and I do not want it to be yours. This game (even though I stated it was good for enthusiasts etc...) makes dept a real issue and if you're stupid enough to add all of the DLCs to the cart then you might as well get another bank account. I may play it an awful lot, but honestly the outdated graphics may be the best for a train simulator, but the development company to take over this game hasn't evolved since the 1998. The trains do look excellent, but the AI are all the same in effect only retextured to the time period or the characters gender. I'd say a 4/10 would be being pleasant to the developers but it isn't a good choice for Christmas. I would plead you not to purchase an absorbing 2009/10 based sim that hasn't been updated (as in the bugs fixed or graphice improved) since its release.

reviewText:
I cannot recommend this for anything outside of the German rail routes.  And, even some of those are bugged out.

General Issues:
- Routes suffer from 2 locomotive, 3 car syndrome.  Any more costs money, and usually have to be manually added in via modding if you want to actually see them on a train other than the one you yourself are driving.
- Expensive DLC.
- No indication if the dead man's switch is alarming from outside of the cab view.
- Cannot disable the dead man's switch.
- Seems to not be well optimized:  has periodic performance issues on even high end hardware.
- Some of the scenarios have long introductiory npc scripts where you end up waiting for 5-10 minutes just for the first block to clear.

Bugs:
- DLC routes are often missing from 1 or more of the game modes.
- Dead mans switch fails to operate correctly.  It sometimes just fails to deactivate without explaination and eventually kicks on the emergency brake.
- Emergency break kicks on unexpectedly, even if keeping up on the dead man's switch, and sometimes cannot be reset, breaking some scenerios.
- Game will insist that you are exceeding a speed limit, even when you are not
- Game will sometimes not tell you that the speed limit changes ahead until it's too late.
- The times between stops in scenerios are often so tight that you cannot reasonably make it in time.  This is sometimes so obvious that you can't make it even with full throttle, full brake, and breaking the speed limit.
- Switching on main lines in some scenerios and on free roam will inexplicably be routed into sidings and into parked NPC trains.
- Dialog missing/nonsensical on some scenerios, even on introductory ones on flagship routes.
- Occasionally a scenario will fail because of a hickup while coming to a stop:  Complaining that you went underway again without completing the objectives of the stop.

Other thoughts:
They at least fixed the bug where you got penalized for sounding the horn when going past a whistle post.

reviewText:
Updated 26 Feb 15 following comment and release of the Isle of Wight fixes.

You might think it would be fun, or at least different, to be able to drive a steam train, or indeed any train through rolling countryside, perhaps relaxing and a change from killing stuff. If so please look elsewhere.

The idea is good and I know simulations are not for everyone but the implementation is dire. There are repeated bugs and crashes and every update seems to introduce new problems without fixing the old ones.

There are 2 sides to this game. Driving stuff and building stuff in the editor.

Driving first.

Having never driven a train I cannot say if the simulation side is accurate, what I can say is that the missions and game play can be frustrating.

You get a handful of trains and routes from the outset and can purchase any number of additional DLC from Dovetail (or whatever they are calling themselves now) and 3rd party devs. There are missions where you have to take a train from one place to another in a tight time-table without speeding, falling of the tracks,crashing or going through a red signal which is harder than it sounds. Trains do not stop quickly, or like rain, hills etc so running on time is tough and it is very easy to miss a speed restriction resulting in a failure (or no awarded points).

Missions can last over a hour and you will loose if you go through a red signal, or make a serious mistake,. There is a quick save (press F2 - thanks paned) but to reload you have to quit the mission and then reload from the mission select screen. Some of these routes are very long and take quite a time to load. You only get one save slot per mission and so even doing a reload may not save you if you are about to pass a red signal. Get it right and there is a sense of achievement ( or relief ) but the bugs just get in the way.

There are other computer controlled trains on the line and you can be perfectly on time, top scoring only to have one of these crash miles away from you for the mission to fail. You did nothing wrong, the game bugged. remember how long some of those missions are? Imagine that happening 45 mins into one. It will.

You might like to purchase some of the nice shiny DLC, in a word don't. There is zero, zilch, nada, zip, guarantee that an update won't break it without warning, and never be fixed. When I first wrote this review in Dec 2014 the Isle of Wight career scenarios were totally bugged and would not load and had not since the 2014 update. Well at this has at last been sorted along with over 100 other bugs and glitches for one, rather old, route. OK congrats for at last sorting the problems devs, but you have released countless new bits of DLC in the meantime many of which have their own bugs.

One of my 3rd party routes (can't remember which) has you so that you are embedded in the roof of the train cab making driving 'interesting'. That broke in 2012. Since the original review I have found that some of the wooden post semaphore signals from the UK set have the signal arm at the bottom of the post (so embedded inm the ground), rather than where it should be at the top. I have no idea how long these have been broken, but given the devs priories (new DLC, new DLC etc) don't expect these to be fixed soon if ever.

Building

Hanker after your old train set, want to build a virtual one? Look elsewhere or the bugs and frustration will get you here as well.

The editor is complicated, and you have to do a lot of background reading before you start. Signals are complex things and getting them wrong with cause you no end of problems. This would not be a problem if editor loaded and didn't crash, and allowed you to move a track without sicking buffers all the way along it and has a sane way to build tunnels and didn't crash if you raised a track for a hill and... In short it's bugged as well. As for the documentation welll....

To sum up its a nice idea ruined. The graphics are nice (and bugged - check fully leaved trees that cast the shadows of bare branches, solid walls that have light flooding under their bases etc), and it could be a relaxing way to spend a few hours.

If it worked.

reviewText:
Giving Train Simulator 2014 the thumbs down is a difficult decision, but I'll explain why I feel I am compelled to do so.

I first purchased TS2014 when it was TS2013 / Railworks 3. TS2014 is essentially an updated version of last year's game with a new menu interface and some minor patches. The same routes available prior to the conversion are compatible with the current version.

First, I'll evaluate TS2014 as a game. Graphically, it is probably one of the best looking simulators in the genre, and while the visuals are not cutting edge by any sort, they adequately represent the locomotives, rolling stock, and scenery. Some locations and trains are impeccably detailed and create wonderful scenic panoramas; others are nothing special, but still pleasing, while some models and locales are devoid of details, incomplete, or just plain ugly. Some graphical bugs present themselves, usually missing or clipping textures, but this is largely dependent on the route or locomotive. Certain assets are far more polished than others. Sounds are overall nothing spectacular. They work for the most part, and some locomotives are equipped with awesome sound packs, replete with CB radio voiceovers, the hum of the engines, and great horns and bells. Unfortunately, other trains were not given the same treatment, and sounding the horn is an anticlimactic experience when the sound is muffled or lacks an echo, and instead cuts off the second the key is depressed. Much like visual detail, quality varies with sound and is dependent on the developer of a given asset.

Gameplay is fairly standard for a train simulator; there are no interesting new features or design quirks, and let's be honest, I didn't expect there to be. The standard by which simulators are judged the most is realism, and by and large TS2014 provides a fairly realistic experience. Steam locomotives, as expected, scale in difficulty compared to their diesel and electric counterparts. You are expected to obey signalling and dispatcher orders and are penalized harshly for failing to heed these warnings. Points are awarded for timeliness and subtracted for recklessness and tardiness. There is enough challenge in most scenarios to keep you on your toes; of course, you can free drive, disable all the realism settings, and run the game like MLG PRO EXTREME TRAINZ SIM 420 and surf on rails if you wish.

With all being said, Train Simulator 2014 is a decent game. It looks nice and will engage players who are interested in railroading and simulators in general. However, it is a terrible value, and I hope to illustrate why.

In the Standard Edition, which retails for 39.99 USD, you get the game itself plus three routes (the specific routes have changed since when I purchased the game). These routes range anywhere from a few dozen km (15-20 miles or so) to 300+ km (180+ miles) and provide usually no more than 3 trainsets (some are generous enough to give you 4 or 5) along with anywhere from 5 to 12 scenarios, on average. You're paying a bit over 13 dollars per route in addition to the base game. Fair enough. Where Dovetail Games (formerly RailSimulator.com Ltd.) will suck you dry is through the numerous DLC available for the game, and I would consider Dovetail one of the, if not the absolute worst offenders on Steam in the practice of pumping out overpriced and underwhelming DLC.

Consider that the typical price of a new route add-on is 39.99 USD. I bought the base game and three routes for that same price. What justifies a ludicrous markup of over 200% on additional routes, when some are smaller or less detailed than those included with the game? Moving on to locomotives, you can purchase the Amtrak California Zephyr F40PH (a common diesel found on North American railroads) for 19.99. It comes with one livery and a few missions for a DLC that, thankfully, is now included in the base game, but at one time was a separate purchase. Even more pathetic is the attempt to sell the BR Class J74 tank engine for 7.99 with a few scenarios. But the most egregious example of how bad TS2014's DLCs can get is the listing on Railsimulator.com for a silver livery for the PRR GG1 locomotive for 4.99. Yes, for 5 dollars, you can be the proud owner of one skin. Locomotive not included. This is absurd.

I understand that a lot of content in this game is developed by third parties, and that they need to be paid for their hard work. Yet the price gouging set in place by Dovetail can hardly be justified, especially when the developer's quality control team has a history of overlooking minor and not-so-minor bugs in the DLC they allow to be published, resulting in a wide variation in the quality of the addons. Do they want their game to have a reputation for uncertainty? The exhorbitant prices combined with the developer's curt attitude to criticism by the fanbase drives potential players away and hurts the rating of what otherwise is a decent simulation. The Steam Workshop and the intensely devoted railfan community have the potential to improve this game by leaps and bounds if the developers understood that mod friendliness and accessibility can only help their product.

If you are a railfan and value your money, just go and build a model railway. You will meet more people, gain more useful skills, and enjoy the experience much more than if you buy this game and the accompanying DLC. After all, the cost of all the DLC combined could finance a fairly large-sized model railroad. Besides, you will have more creativity at your hands and create more lifelong memories with that than by investing that money into Train Simulator 2014.

reviewText: The world’s favorite train simulator eh? I sadly must disagree. I bought this game thinking it would be cool. But apparently, all I purchased was a “demo” with a cool background. Over half the missions require maps that you don’t even have. And these DLC maps aren’t cheap. Each of these DLC maps cost $20+. It’s basically just a demo. You don’t even have half of the necessary content to play this game as if it’s the real thing. I was very disappointed. Once you get in the game, you see a store with a very cool background. So basically all you purchased for $60 is a demo with a few maps and a DLC map store (don’t forget the very cool background), so that you can spend more money. If you really like trains, go ahead and buy some of the DLC. But I recommend staying away from this game. To “upgrade” your game to the full version, you would need to buy all of the DLC to make the game fully functional. This could cost up to $1000. The gameplay is very nice, but there isn’t much to do at all without the DLC. I have some of the DLC content but it doesn’t make much of a difference if you don’t buy all of the necessary DLC. I hope that there are better train simulators, or that this one will make all the DLC free. If the DLC came with the game, this would be a very good train simulator. Until they make it free, I’ll be watching that very cool background.

Few games manage to get worse when the developer continues to work on them. But this is one of them.

For whatever reason, the developers of Railworks Train Simulator changes things that doesn't need changing, adds things that doesn't need to be added, and yet, doesn't fix what needs to be fixed.

In my opinion, this game is not worth buying. When i first got onto this game, it was the 2012 edition, with the 2013 edition being better in a few ways, but this 2014 edition is awful. There is a career system with icons and graphics that look like they were quickly made in MS-Paint, nothing has improved as far as i can tell, and old routers/scenarios are still bugged. For the casual player who wants to have fun driving a train, i honestly wouldn't recommend this at all. It's frustrating trying to get a good score, when suddenly with no warning the speed limit changes, which seems to happen on alot of routes. Saving and returning to the game isn't fun when the load times are this long.

And for whatever reason; i have performance problems.
My game runs on a AMD Radeon 7970 GHz edition, FX-6300 OC'd, and is on a Corsair SSD, but, when i drive a train at a high speed the map sort of loads in chunks"

reviewText:
If you want laser-cannon firing trains that shoot out spikes to kill aliens, then don't bother. But if you want a game that is strangely absorbing and relaxing at the same time, requiring almost no skill to enjoy but weeks of practice to really be an expert, TS ticks all the boxes. I can see why the shoot-em-up fans don't 'get' this game, but I really do. You struggle to get up a hill with a thousand tons of freight behind you, then worry about running away down the other side. Or you have to pick up on time at every station, stopping literally within a couple of feet of the marker on the platform. Or drive along a country route enjoying the scenery and watching out for interesting trains coming the other way.

It's pretty much the only Steam game I play, it's got so much extendability - driving a freight train in the snow is VERY different to driving the same tracks with an express train at night in the rain. It not only makes me respect train engineers/drivers much more, it provides me with a lot of pretty harmless fun. Oh, and unlike so many games, it's one that I'm perfectly happy to let my son play. He is SO impatient but he is quite happy to take a two-hour trip on TS.

Highly recommended (unless you think GTA V is the bestest experience of your life, in which case probably not).

reviewText: Visually this is a great game.  For me, that's about where the positives ended.  I like a variety of games and don't need constant action but this was tedious.  I especially enjoyed when I arrive at stations and had to sit and wait for 3-5 minutes (real time) to elapse to leave the station on time.  The controls for the trains I have require me to have to either constantly hold the throttle or keep losing speed then have to shift back down to not lose points for speeding.  I guess the people who made the real trains these are modeled after never found a way to have linear controls that would stay in place so instead you have 25, 50,75 and 100% power or you hold the throttle in place at a mid point for 3-10 minutes as you travel.  Don't read the speed limit signs or follow their map or you will lose points for speeding when you hit the occasional bug in the game where the programing doesn't match the visual cues.  I can't bring myself to do a single scenario that will take 3-4 hours.\n\nTo buy all the DLC for this game when it is all on sale gave a price of over $1,500, I think this may be the most expensive game in existance.

reviewText:
It's kind of a love-hate-relationship.

On the one hand it very likely is the worst simulator in history and not a good game either. It suffers from lots of bugs - huge ones in a simulator like wrong acceleration values of a simulated train resulting in rocket train behaviour or plain wrong diesel tank volume because the devs messed up the liters-gallons-conversion to smaller ones like switches being flipped upside down etc - and super low quality assets like textures with a 90s look an resoution and bad modelling like a round switch not beeing round but an octagon. Also the developer rarely EVER updates the simulated stock so when a DLC has a bug it will stay that way. Another HUGE issue is the sound department as most sound assets are laughably bad. Like heavy freight wagons often having no sound at all. Seeing them glide by like hover cars will make you cry and laugh at the same time.

On the other hand DLC from thrid parties (like Reppos GP20, like the Constallation from Smokebox, like the Class 90 from Armstrong Powerhouse, ...) is brilliant with proper sound, proper realism and proper attention to detail and good quality assets. Driving one of those on a nice route (Stevens Pass for example) that is a labor of love from a third party developer and not the usual rushed and buggy junk is incredibly fun.

Overall I cannot reccomend this game. While there are combinations that shine (Smokebox Constellation over Marias Pass or Class 90 along the West Coast Main Line from Keith Ross or the Meshtools Jinty on the Western Lines of Scotland), the majority of content ist ... sadly though ... junk. Badly buggy with worse sound and low quality textures and modelling. While you will get a nice collection of worthy content you will also collect a huge amount of content straight of RSCs trashbin.

And it's not even about the price of DLC as ther is quite some DLC that is worth the full price like the already mentioned stuff and other 3rd party content. It's the attitude with which RSC treats you and this sim. They don't give a damn, they release buggy DLC over and over and over again. They are not interested in improving. They are not listening or updating their own stuff, they just want to sell you new stuff.

While the core might be a nice but badly aging platform for third party developers that actually care, the affiliation with the main developer RSC poisons this whole sim. So one can only reccomend to stay far far away.

reviewText:
Its a quite fun game if you dont feel like doing anything but there are simply not enough routes incuded with the standard package (which I bought) or with the Steam edition. For this reason (and the ones stated below) I can't reccomend the game. If you really want to buy the game, wait till its on sale. Plus the over £2,000 of DLC is just insane.

There are many reviews saying that the game has bugs, and it has many of them; engine + break sounds on DB Ice train sound seriously unrealistic (they're not smooth, they go in incriments), the Hamburg to Hannover route ends abruptly, the thing that shows if you're going to tip goes from middle to side really fast if you go past the orange zone and the people walk  incrediby unrealistically, or are just seriously hungover and have serious knee problems.

td;lr of below: This game doesnt feel like a simulator or like you're driving a heavy train, is missing tons of features, is really buggy and feels more like an arcade game.

There are many other problems such as not most of the inside of the train isnt controllable which dissapoints me (I like pressing random buttons and watching the warning screens go mental), the route builder is just unintuitive, menu's are complicated, there is no loading menu procentage (however this is minor compared to the rest of the problems), no weather effects when out of cabin view, train textures go really bad once you go out of the cabin view, animation glitches (one of them is the blinds on the DB train merge through the roof) and world textures sometimes are awkward because they dont graduate from other ones.

I also feel that the physics engine is not there, the speed settings seem to have max speeds they can go (no engine torque simulation from my experience), the derailment looks awkward. It quite simply doesnt feel like you're driving a heavy train (brakes are instant and its really quick to throttle up).

The point system is a good idea but too mean (I mean, speeds randomly changing from 60>40>60 and you're getting penalised for the sudden, unshown change) and the drive quality penalty makes no sense as it doesnt feel like you're going too harshly around the corners.

The world doesnt seem too real either; the sounds are off. When I'm in a city I expect to hear cars, when I'm in the countryside I expect to hear birds and wind blowing and its just not there. On the subject of weather, the droplets (even though done nicely with the dropping animation) are square and seem to ignore wind and the smearing" effect of the wind and nothing looks wet.

Overall out of the 14h played it was fun to the extent of pressing the A and D keys and occasionally the Q key when the British highspeed train (class 395) starts beeping like something's about to blow up. If you're looking for a game which feels "arcadey" and not doing much this is the game for you.

Edit 1: Corrected some grammar/spelling errors."
voteText: 13 of 16 people (81%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
PROS:
- Convincing simulation: In cab controls (lots of dials/switches/buttons), conducting each train feels different and unique enough to be a new experience
- Built-in scenario/map creator
- Difficulty scalable from practical free roam to very strict failure
- Trains are modeled nicely, pretty to look at
- Variety of camera controls
- Tutorials (can even learn a lot about how trains function IRL)
- Tons of DLC to add variety (this is a PRO assuming that money is not an obstacle)

CONS:
- Base game feels bare and stripped of content, DLC almost required to keep interest
- Sound is unpolished/unfinished: trains virtually silent, very little ambient/cabin sound (no immersion via audio at all)
- Graphics specifically pertaining to scenery are awful (trains look great, but you're going to spend hours staring at fugly low quality scenery)
- Performance: even on a high end machine, you can count on regular FPS drops and chattering of all sorts
- Game play (almost by nature) is very repetitive, with long periods of do-nothing.  After ~20 hours, I'm done with it.
- Technical difficulty galore... occasionally patches will break the game and leave it unplayable for months on end.
- Very little to no developer/community relationship and communication

GOOD BUY?
I regret buying this game even at the sale price at the time.  If you absolutely love trains, I would still wait for a deep deep sale.

RECOMMENDATION SUMMARY
I can't recommend because the cons outweigh the pros by a fairly large margin.  The core of the game is great fun, but where the idea is nice, the execution and details completely fall through.  Adding salt to the wound:  terrible community relations, technical support (most of my emails/tweets/communication went completely unanswered - still have pending support request unresolved from a half year ago).  Even though the game has its fun moments, it's fraught with holes, and is not good value.

reviewText: So I got this game on a DVD format.After running into issues from the get-go, the installation requiring about 45GB of free space,I ran into the real issues of this game.To avoid deleting stuff to make space for that insane requirement, I activated the game key through Steam and downloaded the game like it. Final installation,about 8GB. Then I launch the game. This is the game with the longest load in the history of gaming,so be prepared for that. In the game you're gonna see a list of scenarios, but fear not...clicking to complete most of them will pop up a window asking you to buy stuff.Like the route,the train,etc.Turns out very very few content actually comes with this game (about 3 routes and 8ish locomotives).Rest is paid DLC, with price tags of about £20+.Being ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off beyond belief I tried to get rid of it. Returning the game however is not an option.Steam doesn't reply to e-mails, they don't offer refunds for physical items not from Valve Store,and the shop I got it from won't take it back as well,seeing I already opened it. So my advice to you: STAY AWAY from this.It is a blatant rip-off, overpriced with essentially no content, that performs bad and messes with hardware.A very bad venture between Railworks and Steam with no way to get a refund,which also I think it might be illegal. And if you do not believe me,feel free to browse the internet for other reviews on this. Again I emphasize: Stay away!

reviewText:
First off, I really enjoy the game. The game itself is enjoyable, controlling the speeds, directions, hooking up cars, switching tracks, etc. It really is enjoyable. I bought the Holiday Express pack during the sale for only $3.00. Well worth three dollars. I'm glad I didn't pay the full twenty. There were only a handful of scenarios which took no time to complete. Plus, being the Holiday pack, I only got the Holiday train, despite Steam now insisting I own the full version. Here's the first problem.

To have anything else to do, I have to be willing to spend $20 to $30 to unlock more trains and locations. If they are as basic as the Holiday set, total ripoff. And since the total to purchase all of the DLC is over $3000, I can pretty much guess the small amount of content in each pack. Shame too.

If this game would include a more broad scope and not be so limiting in the initial purchase, I could see playing this for quite some time. Unfortunately, there really isn't enough to do. And if you are thinking Workshop mods"

reviewText:
EDIT: The fact the Dovetail Games does not really have much competition in the train sim genre kind of begs the questions why sell the DLC as these ridiculous prices, let me tell you why, there numbers are dropping and they struggle to maintain healthy continous playing users, lets looks at another game like Euro Truck Simulator 2, they have DLC not many but they have some and are all ridiculously cheap and they even give players free noticeble game changing updates, Dovetail Games doesn't, SCS have one thing that Dovetail Games doesn't a strong continuous player base that play most of the time, look at the numbers for yourself on the steam stats they are one of the top 10 games that get played daily, train sim doesn't have that player capture towards a game that Euro Truck is, and this is why Dovetail games struggle and force the high DLC prices just to stay alive, they are expanding there company having over 100 employees that very difficult to maintain if the numbers are not showing and now they have DTG Fishing and FSX under their belt. This is why Ladies and Gentlemen Dovetail Games have these high DLC prices and this why the game haven't significantly changed from day 1 all those years back, DTG have grown to comfortable with this routine of pumping out medicore DLC at these high prices as its the only thing they can do to just keep them in busniess, if they had more players playing the game daily like Euro Truck has DLC wouldn't be that expensive. DTG need to get the next train sim right, they need to listen to the players for once (not saying they dont) but the whole model of the game needs to change from where it is now!
Well time for me to contribute my review for Train Simulator as a whole franchise.

First even though I do recommend the game it isn't the perfect simulator everyone expects however.

Lets go over the positives about this game to not sound to anti Train Sim:
PROS:
- This game overall is very good and solid for a Train Simulator; it does all the basics you would want from a simulator; get in train different trains on different routes (all covered)
- Graphics are genrally pretty good (but I will elobrate a bit more in the cons)
- It is now a very user friendly game and new comers will find it extremely easy and fullfilling to get into the game and start driving
- The Steam workshop intergration is one of my biggest pros for this game (it in some ways saved the game from being forgotten about) you have access to free community made scenarios which are far better then ones Dovetail Gmaes try and make with each DLC route, there is always someone you can find on the steam workshop
- It is sort of immersive I guess....
- For the DLC collection they have to offer it isn't that bad but more can be done (I will talk about pricing in the cons)

and well.... thats all I can really think of for the pros currently, it a solid simulation that is great for new players to get into ...

But I am not a new player so for long lasting players maybe some of the pros I mentioned are relateble.

Now the CONS (sit tight)

- DLC pricing.... This is a whole topic for itself: Since the beginning of Train Simulator DLC weren't the cheapest but were reasonable, in the present day I personally think DLC is way overpriced for what you do get. The standard game has also increased so more money to spend if you are getting into Train Sim.
Dovetail games has increased as a company and has a much larger player base then it once had, I do not understand why that should mean to increase DLC price it is obsurd! A route generally costs £25 with any additional trains (that they do not bother to add with the standard route) adding on another £11 to £15.............. this is just way too much money to keep investing into, the most smartest/desperat time for players to get DLC is during steam sales (imagine if they didn't exist?)

- DLC Routes & Trains: Adding on from the pricing point of view.... Routes and train have come a long way through the history in Train Simulator no one can deny that detail has gotten better over the years. But I do not think it is good enough, routes to me do not feel very unique most assests are copied over from other routes e.g. most station exteriors and interiors are just plain simple and copied, they only add sometimes big nice fancy details to show of a particular place in one area of the route. Trains are even more disgusting to think about sure again things have improved but not enough (WHY DO WE HAVE 3RD PARTY WEBSITES like Armstong Powerhouse [which they do a fabulous job] having to step in to fill the gaps dovetail games miss out?) The Class 321 is probabaly the best exmaple of this the one dovetail game released was a total shambles, and then AP released their version with better visuals and sound (especially), it makes you wonder why can't dovetail games include these more improved features? We pay large prices for them? And then you have AP who does a better job for the fraction of the price......

- GRAPHICS ENGINE: Ok this is proabably my most passionate point and I know that TS 2016 is the year where an upgrade to Unreal Engine 4 is due but let me elaborate my concerns for the past few years with this current engine we have!
The graphics engine is just too old now. This game have been out for 6+ years and we have been faced with the same PhysX engine and frankly its showing it age! When I said the game is quite detailed I ment only to a point, of course is massively better then an 8-bit game but in the present day with many advancing graphic engines and great game looking games being produced you would think something like a simulation game as one as popular as Train Simulator can have the same treatment. The current engine prevents dovetail games from making far larger maps (which is something many complain about), high 0fidelity of textures is something that cannot be achieved in the current engine; certain assets and textures currently look so terrible and can be compared to a game of ten years ago, Dovetail games only focus on certains things to catch your eye from the reality of the surrounding game!
MULTIPLAYER: This actually links to the graphics engine issue, the current engine apparently wouldn't be able to handle lets say a open world multiplayer" which I think is so needed in a popular simulator like Train Sim (I have talked in my youtube video about the lack of connecting the community and friends together with this game
date: it discourages a connection between player and the achievement system in the game now is just such a bad attempt of dong something to make it look like your friends are involved with your gaming experience. Any the whole multiplayer issue is much deeper than this so I won't carry out but you get the point.\nANNIMATIONS: Again to the with the engine

reviewText:
The game has potential. It can be fun, if you're into realistic train simulation. The trips can be boring, but if you want realism, you have it.

Many of the cool trains need to be bought separately at really high prices (like EUR 19.99). I felt cheated.

But the biggest frustration is with the game performance. It's *extremely* slow. According to Fraps, it runs at 7 FPS on my computer, which is able to do much more complex games just fine - including Titanfall. When another train appears in the screen, FPS drops even further. I tried tuning down a few settings but it's still quite bad. It's awful.

reviewText:
This game is not as good as the rest of the train simulator series. I have to say this is the most disappointing of all, mostly because of the lousy interface but also because of the lack of trains and routes you start with. The DLC is too expensive and you do not get steam trains included with your first trains. I would not recommend this game to anyone unless you are prepared to spend lots of money on DLC routes and trains.

On the plus sides the graphics have improved as well as the in-game physics, but what happened to the train simulator I once loved. Bought this game for my brother with high hopes they would have included good trains again such as the Flying Scotsman and Orient Express which was once included in the game, but Trains like these can only be obtained via DLC.

To sum this game up, Despite the great graphics and physics. It has an awful interface, There are a lack of decent trains and comes with very few routes unless acquired through costly DLC.

reviewText:
RSC now DTG their product TS2014 , while looking slick with nice Hd graphic's & other tricks, this product is not a Simulation.
The history of this game date's all the way back to Microsoft Train Simulator & Kuju Entertainment, when MS dropped the project Kuju Entertainment returned with the simulation Called Rail works 1 & 2 .

At this point RSC brought the game rights from Kuju Entertainment & took over the project re-naming it Train Simulator they also carried over all the bugs effecting the Sim too.

The product moved onto the Steam platform to make it much simpler to update the game year in year out, so TS2012/13/& 14 are just evolutions & not a new product,

Many of the same bugs have been carried over with each update, also each update had led a  nightmare of broken add-on's that have stopped working of simply fail to show up in the menu both from 3rd parties & DTG DLC too.

Most of the update have seen the the game go from been a more Sim based product to a arcade feel game.
Add to that the fact that DTG Support as a well documented history of been poor at best, there forums are not much better.

There is also the endless stream of what would call over price DLC most of which just add's to the list of errors & bug's already effecting the game

I would steer clear of this product If you are looking for a real Train Simulation & not just a over priced digital Train set at best.

If you are into simultions you will be let down by this one for sure.

reviewText:
Ok, just don't buy this game. It sucks on every aspect. It's not worth your time. You'll be judged by everyone. It's horrible, I run this game at 20 fps with all graphics turned up with a dual gtx 780i... If you can see this, leave this page and never come back!

reviewText:
THE ULTIMATE TS2014 REVIEW

The game does exactly what it says on the tin. And I'm not sure if that's a good thing or not. If you are a huge fan of trains (like a certain character from an overrated TV show) then by all means pick this up and you will probably get many wet dreams over it. But for everyone else who see trains as a rather average transportation method to get you from Point A to Point B, then you won't get much out of this game, hence why I don't play this game.

Razey's Score:
3/10

reviewText: This is without a doubt the worst supported application on the planet. I am a game developer myself and, while a one man shop, I manage to provide answers and support to my customers. reviewText:
PROS:
- good game if you are a train enthusiast.
- intro video is neat
- i really cant say much. just too much wrong with this game

CONS:
- game is very unpolished. things like the narration dialog boxes feel cheap and the additional hud controls seem like they can be so much better.
- train horns suck. you can hear the looping, which is dead obvious on certain engines, and it doesnt even play back as you intend most of the time.
- zoom mechanism is very shoddy when in 3rd person. if you 'ram' the camera down into the car behind the engine in focus, it'll push the camera location out and away. yet when you scroll, it basically crops and zooms the visible area of the camera without actually moving it TO the engine in focus.
- - not only 3rd person, but it really needs to be improved in general. it seems too constricted to pre-set areas. especially when going through tunnels and such.
- the headlights seem nearly ineffective. like the only thing it's doing is giving the engine a lit up look.
- and my biggest complaint: so much expensive DLC yet every one i've tried has an issue with it. things like a train coming at you head on whenever you get to a certain point, with no way to avoid it or complete the scenario. or improperly set timings. or random unmarked speed zones which slaughter your points, forcing you to restart if you want to make gold. or any metal for that matter.
- objectives seem unclear or confusing at times
- just general bugs, inconsistencies, problems, unpolish.

CONCLUSION:
dont buy this game unless you mind the bugs, unpolish, and are willing to research good packs that dont have any issues.

OTHER THOUGHTS: most companies release software (not just games) on a 2 step cycle: new features, then bug fixes. they push out new features one update, then fix all the bugs the next. rinse and repeat. this company fails to do so. they're more worried about pushing out content as fast as possible than they are about giving us a quality game. its a shame this is the best train sim that's out there. sure, they updated to *better* menus and looks a few times. but its still confusing to navigate. it took me forever to find the community content section within the game, and i wouldnt be able to remember off hand from not playing it for a while.

BEST SOLUTION: redo the whole damn game. and dont come out with any more DLC until you do. and work on fixing and testing the DLC (yeah, its a lot. which is why you shouldve been doing this in the first place). game test a lot and think how can i make this better?" "would i personally play and enjoy this?" "would this be easy for everyone? or just me?"

PS: i dont mean for this to sound negative. i genuinely do want this game to get better. but if they keep going their same path
date: it never will and itll just get worse and worse."

reviewText:
Train Simulator is representative of a franchise that seeks to offer a semi-realistic representation of what it would be like if you were a conductor. The thing is, there isn't really a game here. There is very little to keep you interested for more than a few minutes unless you're playing the game ironically for some sort of media-review or livestream event.

There is very little to guide you ingame as to what you're supposed to do and simply getting a game going in career mode is relatively unintuitive. The game tries to push paid DLC at you at every turn (charging extraordinary amounts of cash for things that should have been in the game from the get-go) often times disrupting the obvious methods by which you actually initiate a game session.

If you can get this for really cheap (we're talking under 10 dollars) it might be worth checking out purely for the irony (and if you're planning on playing it ironically to an audience that values your suffering at the helm of ridiculous/broken games).

reviewText:
Still carrying sfter all this time the same major issues both in the quality of its stock and the pretty poor (at times pathetic) physics. Each update does slowly make some things better but then breaks other things.

Just never  buy the DLC at full price.. Im convinced its just a ploy to make the sales seem more attractive but to be honest the sale prices should be the norm for what can often be lillte more than a pretty poor repaint..

And the DLC is the key problem and cause of this simulators new direction .. The new front end and the way the game is marketed have turned it into nothing more than a giant marketplace where all effort is put into producing DLC and little or no effort is placed in fixing issues. Its slowly becoming less of a simulator and more a hornby model railway for you to add shiny trains to.

There have been a cpl of improvements. US routes now have much better asset variation  (Weirdly UK ones still tend to look like clones of each other despite the higher asset count, must be the grey and green)..  And whilst TSX has without doubt made this the best looking TS on the market, it does tend to make evreything look strangely plastic and false.

The final problem ahs to be the level of support which is frankly non existant.. Not only is all criticsm  removed from the forums  but bug reporting is also deleted with the excuse you must email the poroblems directly to them. When you do this you get a robot response and then nothing ..

reviewText:
Sadly, I have to agree with all the negative reviews all over the web about this game.

What potentially, is a great concept, being able to drive a train in several countries, and also being able to build what is essentially your own train set layout, is sadly let down by all the bugs in the game, that have been there for years.

The developers, Dovetail Games (DTG), seem either not capable, or too lazy to solve these bugs that frankly spoil the enjoyment of the game.

They also delete all negative comments in the forums too, which is not a good sign. Thankfully they cannot touch this review!

I can see that this ignorant blinkered attitude from the developers will end up with them going out of business before long.

If you want to keep your hair, steer clear of this game.

500+ hours on this game and Im nearly bald!
voteText: 12 of 16 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Lets clear the air right now. I dont like a simulator that is so real it feals like work when you use it. Also I am not now nor have I ever worked on a railroad. I enjoy ts because its just real enough for you to get an idea about how trains work but not so real you could go out, hop in a train and drive it away. The realism level of this program is on the same level of farming simulator. If you are Mr. Ultrarealsimulation Do NOT get this. You will be disappointed. If you are a railfan who enjoys casual train operation you will probably enjoy this. With that said, if you are the casual railfan, The DLC is mind blowingly expensive. You cannot even begin to comprehend how much money you could spend purchasing enough DLC to make this more enjoyable. If you think you  will get the vanilla version and call it good, you are mistaken. The standard version comes with three routes and only a handful of locomotives and no steam engines at all. If you want any more routes or locomotives get your wallet out and dont bother putting it away. Even if you want any of the free crap avaliable at the steam marketplace you will first need to have the necessary DLC and that will cost you dearly. If you are new to the franchise, there is a pretty steep learning curve. It doesnt help that the ingame tutorials suck as well. Support? What Support? I have not had one good experiance with the support team. All I got from the support team was a standard response and no fix to my problem. I emailed them back a second time and they essentially told me, Too bad for you, we wont be fixing anything any time soon.
Even with all the issues, I still very much like the game and I do not regret getting it. I wish there were fewer problems with it and I wish it was cheaper to get the DLC. But like they say Deficate in one hand wish in the other see which one gets filled first. That is why I cannot recommend this. There is no intent on fixing known issues and bugs. I am willing to overlook these bugs, but, unless you really like trains, there are too many problems and the staff doesn't care about these problems. On top of all that, the thing is stupidly expensive. You would think for such an expensive product, there would be fewer bugs but that is not the case. Its a shame though because this title has so much potential.


EDIT: 10/14
Got the new update. I now use TS 2015. What the folks at TS did to update the simulator was to make my PAID FOR content vanish like a fart in the wind. DO NOT BUY. Instead of fixing problems they released a new version and now there goes several of my hard earned bones. This is a title with much potential but the developer keeps getting in the way of what could be a wonderful simulation game.

reviewText:
It's difficult to review this... In itself it doesn't look bad. The tutorials could have been better - you're now doing the same things over and over for each type of train.

My main problem is that the game doesn't include much: a cargo route in Germany, a cargo route in the US and a passenger steamtrain riviera route.

There's enough available - but at those prices hardly anybody buys it. I think if they halved their prices they would sell a lot more (and I guess their profit will be higher). There are some routes I've got my eye on, but I'll only buy them in a sale with at least 50% off.

So due to the prices and lack of content in the base game it's a negative...
