reviewText:
This game is fun but it has TONS of FLAWS! It even has FATAL FLAWS! This makes the game WORST!

Here are the examples.


1. Overpriced DLC

The most expensive price for route DLC is $39.99. The most expensive loco DLC is $29.99. I could by a game cheaper than it's most expensive DLC. The most expensive route DLC shoud be only $15.00. The most expensive loco DLC should be $6.50.

2. DLC System

Also on the Holiday Express it says go 100 MPH but the speed sign says 25,30,45 when the 100 MPH limit does not go away. And they care more about DLC then bugs.

3. Impossible To Do

Lets say I want to make a custom loco. I have to use RW_Tools. There is no loco editor in the game or the Railworks folder. Plus RW_Tools cost money. If I want to use any wagon or locos in the quick drive train creator, It only lets me do certain locos and wagons.

4. Bugs

The game will create dump files randomly. Not just my computer but a gaming computer has these problems as well. I played this game on a gaming computer before and it still creates dump files. My Isle Of Wight DLC has some bugs. When I play on of the scenarios the scenario crashes.

5. Unpredictable

Let's say I want to drive a train. Sometimes wheel slips happens unexpectedly while i'm driving a train.

6. Requires gaming computer.

I don't have a gaming computer, here is my computer hardware information.

Intel(R) Pentium(R) CPU B950 @ 2.10GHz 2 Core

4GB RAM

7.Worst Then EA

I did not think there could be a company worst then EA. Well there is, it's name is dovetail, they created railworks and we all know how bad it is. Some of us.

8. A message to the game developers

I just want to say this Why are you making people not want to play this game." With your overpriced DLC and lack of bug fixing it is making the people not want to buy TS2014 but would rather buy Trainz

reviewText:
The very first thing you might ask is why a lot of people that gives negative reviews, actually have more than 100 hours invested into the game. This is firstly because of the compulsory upgrade of the game that the developers push, so a lot of people you see with 600 hours when the game released last year, owned the previous version of the game and invested a lot of hours into it before it became TS2014.

This is not MSTS
In regards for myself, I started playing the old Microsoft Train Simulator and invested hundreds of hours into driving the Japanese fast trains and enjoyed that game fully. When Railworks released, I downloaded it through other means and played some of the older routes with the diesel engine on the UK maps which combined with the broken game was kind of boring.

When TS2014 released, I actually believed that it was of course the same developers as Railworks, but that the engine was completely new and that the only reason there was so much DLC to download and buy was because of backwards compatibility. Jokes on them for doing such an excellent job marketing the new version of their game and dibs on me for digging through 70 EUR worth of DLCs just to come to a boring conclusion about the game: It is not complete.

If you start out by buying the steam version of TS2014 with the UK, German and US standard routes, you'll be amazed at the nice graphics and 3D cockpits as well as the scenarios. But when you've beaten all the scenarios on expert mode with golden stars or 990+ XP and you are only 6 hours into the game, you ask yourself why a big sandbox open ended game with unlimited potential, only have 6 scenarios for each route and approximately 3 scenarios per vehicle.

Where is the content at?
So here comes the hook: You are the missing link, you are the missing developer. They expect us to learn how to use the editor (which you can't even exit using the ESC button) and has lots of illogical and unintuitive controls. It is not only frustrating when you have to spend 10s of hours on youtube watching 13 year old German kids explain the editor in broken English (Zumindest nehmen Ihre Zahnspange aus, wenn Sie sprechen.); at the end finding yourself with a perfect scenario where each train goes and leaves in perfect timing. This is where you press the fast forward button, make all the trains move from their starting locations and then press the Test Scenario" button. What happens when you do this you ask? The scenario will save itself as if the current time stamp was the beginning of the map and you have to remake the whole scenario from the beginning
date:
because the editor automatically saves over your scenario without you having to confirm a save.

Steam Workshop
But the Steam Workshop will add the missing link between the missing content and the customer developer. It gives the users the powers to upload their glorious expert scenarios to the cloud and can easily be subscribed to by the click of a button. This is of course if one of the customers get past the initial learning curve of the stupid UI in the editor and after at least 3 hours of testing and time table experiments gets a mission working
recommended: he uploads his contribution to a filter based browser that gives us much more content. Out of the 30 subscribed scenarios I've downloaded on the UK London-Faversham high speed route
hoursPlayed: 2 of them worked

reviewText: When you buy into the TS franchise what you're really getting is a game engine, a platform, and a pretty average one at that when you consider the graphics and stability. This really isn't a proper game until you start buying the addons and DLC, and a quick browse of the obscene prices will leave most new customers feeling a bit nauscious.\nIs it worth the investment? reviewText:
I grabbed this ages ago on hefty Steam discounts... And, that's honestly where the value is.

+ 2015 version has great UI
+ Fun to drive trains
+ Interesting tutorials
+ lots of workshop content
+ started with 2013 edition, free upgrade to 2015
+ some free DLC (known as Classic Routes in the workshop)
+ career system seems interesting so far

- some tutorials need better explanations (ie: when breaking, explaining what wheel slippage is and why it happens would be nice.. or the right time to start slowing down when a speed limit is changed, etc)
- even with beefy spec'ed machine I still lagged out in certain areas
- graphics could be plenty better or at least better polish
- riddled with bugs
- insane base price
- insane DLC prices

My positive and negative bullet points basically sum it all up. It's a neat game, and there's a lot of great stuff here. But is it worth $60CAD? Heck no, not compared to so many other titles out there. Why is that? Because for AAA prices, I don't want to see ID Not Found" when trying to create my profile. I don't want to see lag or framerate drops on my high-spec'ed machine every time I pass through a town - and all the other little bugs. This is further worsened by the DLC prices - when they are priced the same as full-version titles
date: and I can read about how they have the same craftsmanship (aka riddled with bugs)
recommended: I'm just not going to take the chance at getting burned.\n\nAnd that is disapointing
hoursPlayed: because I like sinking my teeth in detailed sims; and I'm not afraid of opening my wallet and investing considerable sums into a game to support it... But when the title is riddled with bugs
voteText: the content (such as the tutorials) need further ironing out and so on
helpfulPercent: you cannot justify these prices - no matter how niche-market the title is.\n\nI guess I can conclude this all by saying that in the end

votesTotal: and B) because my base copy keeps getting updated for free; so it's hard to really feel ripped off. So I am enjoying it - but I'm disappointed because I feel like my replay value is going to be capped until I can get some more DLC for cheap; because I won't be paying their regular price that's for sure.\n\nI wish I could say maybe on the reccomendation... but it has to come down to this: until they drop their base prices for the game and the dlc to something more fitting the quality of the game you're getting right now

reviewText:
I have owned this game on Steam for about four years, I think.  Been awhile anyway.  I have enjoyed it, although every year when they update, the experience has tended to deteriorate as apparent inefficiencies and bugs are introduced.   It's fun if you enjoy train simulators and is probably the best on the market from that perspective.

Yes, there is a lot of DLC, and yes getting it all would cost a small fortune.  This really hasn't affected me a great deal since it is still far cheaper than the model trains and accessories I collect.  There is absolutel no requirement to buy any DLC to enjoy the game as intended.  DLC is just an expansion, much like a new set of tracks and models is an expansion to a model rail display.

That said, I do not recommend this game to new players.  As noted, its quality is getting worse.  Support is essentially non-existent.  The community can be toxic.  It's not fun anymore.

With the release of 2016, I can no longer play any part of the game except the part where you fill out a marketing survey.  Every route is a blackscreen, and the game eventually gives up and crashes.  I am too tired to fight a battle with ignorant techs and seemingly intentionally unhelpful support people so I can do something I should find relaxing.   That's not relaxing; it's infurating, and I am done.

So, uninstall it is, and I'll consider my experiences an expensive lesson in how not to carry on your train hobby once your model set has become too large for your living space.

reviewText:
I once wrote a positive review then I realized that this game is a scam. Why? Because the developers are lack of every aspects of striving for good, because Dovetail probably has no quality management and it's marketing department are made of greedy liars. Let's cut to the chase...

+ Oh, there is a train simulator out there and it looks beautiful

- The game itself isn't optimized a bit. Don't tell me, that this outdated graphic and simulation has so much appetite, that a GTX 750 VGA, a Phenom X2 CPU and 8Gbyte RAM is not enough! On bigger railway stations even with this configuration the FPS drops measurably. To be honest the FPS drops without any input even on high-end desktops and it is probably because of the sloppy programming and the lack of testing and quality inspections. Did I mention loading time? Oh, you can have a dinner but if you are a smoker, one slim cigarette is guarenteed even with the recommended system specs.

- The simulation could be fun until you realize that most of the locos are lack many of the essential controls and most of the switches, buttons are inactive textures serves only for design purposes. Don't tell me that a simple loco has only brakes and throttle, pantograph and headlight switches!

- In many cases the HUD's speed limit signs are not in syncron with the actual railroad tracks vica versa. I don't really use the HUD because it's buggy but if you are driving in career mode with enabled scoring system you are f**ed up, because the game sometimes follows the HUD's speed limitation not the actual railroad signs and again vica versa.

- In most cases PZB is bugged too. PZB (german train control system) is quite hard to master and this game makes it even harder. And by the way sometimes Sifa doesn't work either.

- There are mostly only german, us and british routes available, and it is getting boring. Especially the US routes, those locos are totally inactive ones.

- The greed of the company is unmatched in the game industry. They overprice their DLCs and lie about the features and developements. The whole company is based on low-down marketing. They even delete negative comments from their community forums. What they did with the release of the 2016 edition is the most shameful episode in the history of gaming. They even made a 20 minute youtube video about a new menu which basically is a re-colored one. What an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, really! :-D

You shouldn't buy this game unless you are a railfan! Despite all the negatives it can give you some pleasant time but it's absolutely overpriced and doesn't worth even 10 euros.

reviewText:
(note: this is a review of Train Simulator 2014 / 2015; from a few hours with Train Simulator 2016 it seems extremely similar, mostly cosmetic changes)

Although it's far from perfect, it's probably the best (most realistic) train simulator on the market. (other simulators are mostly glorified model railroad simulators)

It seems to be derived from the Train Simulator that was sold by Microsoft in 2000.

Good points:
- various trains, routes and scenarios. High-speed, main line, commuter, freight, electric, steam, diesel, you name it.
- you get a very good feeling of what driving a real train is like. Accelerating, respecting signals, braking, switching and handling minor incidents to stay on schedule.
- adequate physics, graphics and sounds. Okay this is not up to par with some bleeding edge fantasy games, but frankly, who cares for that on a train simulator?
- nice snow, rain, sunset, night, etc
- realistic signaling on most routes. The software seems to allow a fairly good realism. Not all routes take advantage of that.
-  The London - High Speed Line has a very nice depicting of the French TVM (cab) signalling.

Bad points:

- scenario quality and difficulty are very inconsistent between routes, even within the DTG routes.

For example the ECML route scenarios are realistic and playable (once you have understood the AWS speed checks at 20 mph on warning signal) with adequate spare time to make up for delays, whereas on the München-Garmish route you have to be at max speed all the time, and it's not always enough to be on time. On the Donner Pass scenario, I still haven't understood how to be on time, considering that being at full throttle the whole time doesn't seem to suffice.

Same for braking distances when you encounter a closed block signal: distances are realistic on the ECML route, whereas you just can't possibly brake fast enough on some closed signals in the scenarios of the München-Garmish route. So you have to redo the scenario from that point, braking before seeing the signal, which kills the whole experience.

- you can only handle careers for 1 person. Too bad for families.

- the save/resume system is primitive and doesn't save the whole cab state, some throttle or brake positions can be lost in the process. You can only save 1 point at a time per scenario. There is no way to find the list of saved games, you have to look for that scenario by scenario.

- the French translation is awfully bad. So unbearable I'm hoping I would be able to revert to the English version, but it doesn't seem possible.

- DLCs are waaay, way, way too expensive. Don't buy them, unless you're dying for a specific route or rolling stock. Only buy them in a pack with the game (such as the Steam Edition series) and/or wait for bargain Steam sales which happen about once a year. That way you get a pretty good value for your money.

- the in-game keyboard help is incomplete.

- the ETA system sometimes gives weird results (ETA in the past...). The documentation gives no detail on what computation it is supposed to show (based on max line speed? Current speed?)

- the track display at the bottom of the screen is aged and buggy on some routes (some speed limits are incorrectly shown). The line speeds & ramps & map, etc should be part of the documentation, or accessible from a menu, like in the real world, not limited to the next 2 miles of track on the bottom-of-screen display.

- documentation is lacking. It does a minimal job of presenting the game, routes, signalling rules and rolling stock. Many things you'll have to learn by trial-and-error (especially on scenarios). It is to be found online, when it exists. Supposedly the game provides direct access to it for the DLCs you have installed, but it doesn't seem to work. Plus, it would be nice if it was made available during play, but isn't.

- can't reuse old MSTS 2000 routes and rolling stock. This is sad as there were tons of free routes in all countries.

- not many routes other than UK/US/DE. See above, MSTS 2000 had tons of these.

- no multi-player / online mode. In 2015. Really sad. Lots of fun to be had.

- being able to play as a signalman would be fun, too (see multiplayer above :)

reviewText:
I would really love to be able to give this the thumbs up.....and yet I can't. The potential is certainly there; in fact, it's not that far from being a good game. But at the end of the day you are just met with frustration.

The graphics, considering that this game is 75% about the visual experience, are nothing special though that is hardly surprising given the age of the graphics engine. The physics....well, not knowing what driving a steam engine would really feel like I cannot say that it makes me think I am. But despite these deficiencies I find it strangely compelling to drive a commuter train and there is a real sense of achievement when you have kept it to time.

Then, however, comes the frustrating part. The latest annual update made a whole mess of the game; an unwieldy and counter-intuitive menu system, scenarios which now no longer work, graphical glitches galour and achievements which can now no longer, well, be achieved. And a company which basically does not listen to its customer base but prefers to bury its head in the sand.

A new version with a brand new graphics engine is apparently in the pipeline which will then become the flagship. We are promised that support for this version will continue but I have to ask myself.....given DTG's track record is that really likely given that profits seem to be the be all and end all with customer service rather well down the list?

reviewText:
I had high expectations for this game when I first purchased it, but it seems those expectations were never met.


The gameplay and graphics seemed better than what I had experienced playing older versions of Trainz as well as the variety of scenarios and equipment. However, Trainz runs fine on most regular PCs and they don't make you pay ridiculous amounts of money for more routes and content to add to the game. The DLC for this game is expensive for what it is and when you buy the base game you're not given many routes or equipment thus forcing you to buy the proprietary Dovetail DLC from their store or from Steam. The dynamic lighting feature is tied directly to locomotive headlights that actually produce light, so if you turn it off you get the wonderful sensation of driving a train without being able to see what's ahead of you. The game also has ridiculous system requirements in order for it to run properly. The sensitivity of the scenario scoring is also quite ridiculous as well as some of the ways that the in-game physics work.


I still play this game because I payed good money for the base game as well as the DLC, but I have mixed feelings playing it as well as paying any more money for their expensive DLC. If anything I find playing the other steam games to be better value for game play than this or even just any of my other hobbies compared to this game.


Don't buy this game unless you have a powerful computer and are willing to spend tons of money on actually buying enough content to fully enjoy the game. If anything it'd be better to try and find a different train simulator to play other than this one.
voteText: 12 of 17 people (71%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Train simulator 2016 has been released a few months ago and so it is time to give it a proper review

First things first, this review will not be about prices, I can't give a rats ♥♥♥ about the price of either the game or the DLC. This game is mainly sold on Steam as is the official DLC and Steam has enough sales each year that the price of a game or DLC means diddlysquat. You find the prices to high, wait a few weeks and chances are they drop 50 to 80% for a few days. You are never more than 3 months away from a good deal.

The good

The current incarnation of Train Simulator is Train Simulator 2016. Personally I think it is one of the best yearly updates I have seen for those that bought the new edition. It has some very nice content coming with it, the new menu look is great, the new search works finally like a search should work and the content I played so far is of the better quality. My personal favorite in this years edition is the Union Pacific Gas Turbine also known as the GTEL. The new DB BR155 is a nice German engine as well and the new Riviera in the fifties route with its 5 Steam engines is one of the better route add ons I have seen in a long time. Ok, Sherman Hill and Cologne to Koblenz are reruns but if you didn't already own them they are two good additions for your collection. the Steam edition also packs the Norfolk Southern Coal District and the SD60M. The last one was added a bit later to the pack but everyone that bought the game got the engine regardless.

Also good is the TS rewards that are new this year. If you updated/upgraded to TS2016 you got a pop in after first launch where you could sign up for a newsletter which also signed you up for these rewards. Officially the first rewards are for TS2016 related content but the first reward was given to everyone that signed up even if they had the free update and it was a rather nice yellow boxcar. as extra bonus they added a 20% off coupon for the game for those that had not bought the new addition. The boxcar looks nice and imo stands out from the normal rolling stock you see but I couldn't resist making a reskin for it (as well as for the GTEL) and making a bit of fun with the yellow theme it has. You can find the reskins at http://www.wolfdenmedia.nl/download/the-minion-pacific-full/

The new support system. Not really a TS2016 addition as it is in place for a few months now but my recent dealings with this new system and the people have been... satisfactory. Ok it took you long enough to actually post the correct info on tailsimulator.com and the Steam support topics but I think it is an improvement over the email system you had

The community:  Simply an amazing bunch of people. You will find them on Steam and on several fan sites" like railworksamerica
recommended: Railsim.de and many other country related sites. they are providing the players with first line support

reviewText: Train Simulator 2014 is the best train simulator out of all the other i have play so far, such as trainz. It is much more realistic than all of the other train simulator out there, but the problem is that there is so much bug and glitches that need to be attend to. Some of the bug issue is when starting the engine. The engine won't turn off when you press the key. The biggest glitches that i find is that for some reason the train derail on its own and also froze my whole computer which is really horrible because i have to restart my whole computer again. Also is it possible for you to implement a multiplayer option where other people such as your friends or family member can play with you on the same map. Please fix this simulator, i really enjoy seeing all the incredible and amazing route and rolling stock that the company is releasing to the public. reviewText:
Not even close to the real thing.

Edit: Thought I'd elaborate a little since I wasn't too pleased when I played the game. The game is very pretty, and the trains look very nice. However, the physics are way off, trains lose speed at an extreme rate as soon as you lay off the throttle, and anyone who's ever driven a train know's that is not what happens. Also, even though most many trains today use electronic break systems that can initiate all breaks simultaneously, all freight trains and also passenger trains that are pulled by locomotives still use air powered break systems. These do NOT react with lightning speed as it does in this game.

These two issues are to me game breaking and totally pulls me out of the immersion that the game would otherwise have. If the development team could focus on making the actual driving of the trains more realistic, and by extension fun, they could have a great game that I would probably immensly enjoy. Who knows, maybe then I'd actually buy some of all those million DLC's they keep throwing at us.

reviewText:
I used to recommend this game:
For those who have always wanted to drive a steam train!"

But much has changed since then...
The game has been hijacked by Nvidia
date: if you own an AMD graphics card avoid this game - it looks terrible (anti-aliasing doesn't work - a killer on a game that is based on parallel lines vanishing into the distance)
recommended:
and the performance is terrible.

Also they keep dumbing down the user interface...
It used to be really fun challenge to drive a steam train - personally the only reason I bough the game - but in each of the last two major updates they have reduced the supposed "expert" control system to the point where it is unusable.

I can understand that they may have had some complaints from people unwilling to take the time to learn how to drive the trains properly (steam trains are far more difficult to drive properly - that's kind of the point)
hoursPlayed: but to cripple the game to the point where those that want to cant anymore is just plain dumb.\n\nSo for the time being I just cannot recommend this game to anyone."

reviewText:
Overall a pretty good game but a lot of things let it down.

I am a massive train fanatic, I have always liked trains since I was a little kid, and have even had a few model train sets however my parents soon got fed up of derailing trains crashing their coffee all over the place so this game was the next best thing I could find.

At first sight this game is everything you could want, it comes with a few routes and each of these contain a decent amount of scenarios which are mostly interesting and vary in difficulty. The graphical fidelity of this game is decent but this is 2014 and using 2D trees which rotate to look 3D in this day and age is pretty awful, overall pretty good however soon enough you will have done everything in the base game... so what next?

Well one thing you have to praise is the workshop which lets you download additional routes, scenarios and some other bits and bobs from other owners of the game which are free, and to be honest if this basic feature was not in the game there is no way I would be so positive up till now, so you have to give credit to all the people who have worked hard and given up their time making free content just to make the game more enjoyable, because the developers are too busy making the next stunningly accurate DLC to sell on the store.

Eventually you will want some new routes / locomotives to play around with so you will inevitbale consider paying some hard earned money for some extra DLC which you would assume will be a reasonable price.......... Unfortunately the prices are extortionate and paying £12 just for a locomotive in my oppinion is far too expensive and this is where the game starts to go downhill for me, the DLC is far too expensive and some of the DLC I have taken the plunge on has been very dissapointing. The GEML London - Ipswich Add - On is missing popular stations such as Southend Victoria and Clacton yet I paid £25 near half the price of the game for one route.... for this reason I don't recommend their DLC as you may be surprised to see parts of the route you want are not there!!!

(P.s. the £12 class 90 add-on didn't even have a passanger view??? I am dissapointed by this as other DLCs do have the passanger view, and you don't clearly detail what is / is not included.)

Carrying on, the parts of the route it does include are pretty well done but the platforms on this particular DLC are too short at a majority of stations along the line and whilst I don't expect a 100% replica if your going to take the time to model each station atleast make the platforms the right length? my next issue is that whilst there are very good powerful features to  create / edit routes and scenarios the tools are moderately good but very buggy and will crash often or create errors with little debugging information which is just rediculous and makes these tools somewhat obsolete. I assume this is why the DLC is so expensive?? Not to mention a lack of documentation on how to use these which is a shame, engine-driver is one of many places to find some tutorials however the next part of a tutorial usually never shows up.

To sum it all up, this game is not a bad game, I have played some awful games and as a rail fanatic this game has done a good job of keeping me satisfied, however DLC pricing is out of touch and extortionate, usually not 100% complete or lacking fearues I would consider mandatory personally, the tools they have added to let the average joe create scenarios and improve routes whilst promising and fairly decent are tarnished by their incompleteness and are sometimes at best rather tempermental and require extreme patience. It is for these very reasons I can't recommend this game and I won't be buying any more DLC unless it is dirt cheap.
voteText: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
There are more bugs in this game than there were in Starship Troopers. And of course where you expect bugs you start to assume they are there, making even unbugged decisions in the game unnecessarily irritating. I really want to love this game, they do so much well, but the fact that they do not prioritise dealing with bugs in content they have already released and press on releasing even more buggy content means that I have to give this game a big thumbs down and an even bigger thumbs down to Dovetail Games in general.

Pros
The game looks good, not super awesome, but good.
The sound is very good, and this really draws you in.
They have done a good job gamifying some aspects of the simulation experience, making them more interesting and presenting a gamer a challenge.

Cons
Oh my god the bugs.....
The scenarios are not presented intuitively
There are not enough scenarios for some of the more popular trains
OR they are there, but you need expensive DLC to play them
The DLC is very expensive!

If they did this game even slightly better I think they would be on a winner, but it feels like Dovetail Games is run very poorly.

reviewText:
I purchased Holiday Express to see if I could run TS 2014 and it worked very well, not one issue. I purchased TS 2014 Steam edition with Pacific Surf-liner route. At first the tutorial would crash after starting, with only 2gb (Windows 7 32bit, Quad core) of ram I could see the game would use it all and then crash. I upgraded to 4gb of ram and the game worked for awhile, tutorials, scenarios. Pacific Surf-liner will run for about 15 minutes and crash with either a dump message or a vertex message. I have the game running as low as it possibly can but the issue persists. After searching I have found dozens of people like me who have this experience with little to no help given. Solutions are all over the place from 3gb ram switch for windows to reinstalling everything from .net to flash player. Its rare that I feel cheated by a steam game but when 99% of my library works without a crash and this game generates them within 5 minutes I feel like I deserve a refund.

Please DO NOT ever buy this game or anything made by these people, its a mess that will keep you up nights trying to figure out why the 1 hour long scenario crashes every 15 minutes. I wasted 17+ dollars but you don't have to.

Afterthoughts: After running the game in a window at 1024x768 (previous was 1440x900) it ran on Low detail with very little fuss. I have completed quite a few scenarios and even bought 2 more DLCs before the sale expired (4.49 each, 75% off). I would still not recommend this to people BUT and its a big BUT, if you have a nice gaming rig, a real love of trains and a descent amount of patience you can squeeze some fun from it but for the average person, you have been warned.

reviewText: Go buy Trainz 12 from N3V instead. You will be glad you did. This simulator looks good. Ill give it that. But my praise ends there. Once you look at the extremely pricey content, the lack of easily usable scenario creators, and iron fist control, you realize that they should be paying you to use this game. Lets start at the beginning, This simulator is not cheap, $20 for two locomotives and a set of passenger cars, that is absolutely free for trainz users. In fact, a peruse through the store finds that there is no free content besides user made scenarios that use the content that isnt free... you get the point. Its obvious that the creators did not want you building scenarios, because the process is daunting and more frustrating than the videos above make it sound. Mainly because you are unable to use any content not specifically slated for use on that route. For example, you wish to use a P42 and Phase IV superliners (that you paid $20 for) on Donner Pass to model the California Zephyr. Well, those P42's (While completely common on Donner) are only accessible on the $40 Marias Pass route, so you can forget about a Zephyr. Unless of course you wish to fight the scenario creator and go in via quick drive yada yada yada... The point? Dont buy this game. Seriously, dont.

reviewText:
I recommend this game because its a fun way (though not overly challenging) to drive trains of various types with more or less great realism. I think if you give the game a chance and u like trains, it will give you enough hours of fun.

What I do not recommend about it and why it gets a thumbs down: The career mode scenarios are punishing mistakes too harshly and quickly.
Moreover the prices of the DLCs are ridiculous, to say the least. Given the content delivered, paying almost 30 euros for a route and 15 euros for 1 (!) Loco is really a joke. If the devs want to make this game more attractive to people they seriously need to consider dramatically lowering the prices (ever noticed that the total TS experience will cost u almost 3000 euros??). I waited for some packs to be combined or to get on sale, because otherwise you just throw money out the window.
Also I think compared to Trainz and MTS the variety of train networks and routes is a joke, too. Britain (of course) is overrepresented, and then you have Germany and some west and east coast US routes. Would be nice to see French, Italian, Dutch and other European country's rail networks & Loco's.

It's fun, but dont get any high expectations. And dont spend too much money on the DLC's. They are like 3 times as expensive as they should be.

reviewText: TS 2014 does have some good parts to it.  You get to, at least to some degree, experience driving a train.  The game has pretty decent realism, in the sense that it knows that as more and more rolling stock are coupled, the train gets heavier, longer to stop, slower to speed up, etc.  But I don't think the good parts outweigh the negatives.  For starters, the prices of the add-ons are outrageous.  And it's a total bait and switch, you buy a route, and ooops, you need to go buy a locomotive.  And you aren't buying quality add-ons either.  I think it's fair to say that between all the add-ons that I have purchased, there are not any 2 that deliver the same quality in terms of programming.  All have some bugs, some many bugs.  I have experienced bugs pretty much every time I open the game.  The last drive I just played, I was well under speed limit, on a straight track, and the train just all of a sudden derailed.  Of course, I was about 80% done with the 3 hour drive, and naturally the scenario just ended, so lost all that time.  That's what really sucks is you think you got a drive good, and wham, a big flaw hits, and you are looking at game over.  Anyway, for the money they charge for this game, and all the add-ons, they NEED to really invest into a QA department and not just pocket the profits.  This game could really rock if they actually paid more attention to detail.

reviewText:
I find myself writing a mixed review for this game.

The game in itself is great, nice machines, nice routes, interesting missions and the scenario and route tools allowing you to create your own tracks and missions are a definitive bonus for this game. The graphism aren't bad and the weather system is just great.

Yet despite all those good points I have 3 very negative points :

1 - This game is a resource hog - I can run other simulators like ETS2 full graphism but I can't run this game at the lowest setting without overloading my memory. You will need a 1500Euros computer at least to play this with the minimum requirement, and the graphism aren't that better than the other games.

2 - A lot of issues with the scenarios (missions) preventing them from being successfuly completed. Impossible timetable, wrong reward points setting ( you need a minimum of 900 out of 1000 for the mission to be full success and some mission only gives 700), AI wrongly set preventing you to move. This gives an idea of unfinished work or untested game which saddly  spoils all the fun i could have had. And the fact most aren't fixed after 3 months makes you feel like no one is listening to the customers

and those two points bring me to :

3 - Price : Although I think this game could worth its steep price, the numerous issues presented especially for the scenarios can make you feel ripped off.  The complete game with all extension amounting to over 1000 Euros, one would expect the game to have very little default or at least that the few defects be fixed in reasonable time.

For myself i will stop paying for new content until the contents I have is fully fixed.  I cannot afford to pay over 3000 Euros (new computer + complete collection) for just a game.

my advice is wait till this game is fixed before buying it, or at least dont buy anything if its not in at least a 75% sale

Initial concept was great,the lack of further development in the game engine itself to bring it up to standards of 2014 lets this down in a big way,not to mention the constant $$$$$$ that this game requires.To clear things up pretty quickly,It's not a simulator,and should have never had that word in the title it's just confusing and insulting to simulator fans,it's a game with the emphasis on arcade.

RSC,RSDL,DOVETAIL whatever they are calling themselves thesedays really need to get a grip,you might have the 10 year olds fooled,but not the old timers,a few raindrops and shadows IS NOT cutting edge these days,just take a few moments and visit SIMHQ,there are other sims that offer allot more in terms of visulas ect.

How many years ago is it since the first conception of Rail Simulator?your still packaging the same old trees and vegetation from 7 years ago,that in itself is just unforgiving,not to mention users have to complete routes by adding occlusion themselves,to me this is just as sloppy as you can get.

DLC OVERPRICED,SUBSTANDARD models and sounds,often requires another purchase of a soundpack per loco,so if you paid 10 pounds for a loco - BE PREPAIRED for ADDITIONAL COST.

INGAME ADVERTISING...more pressure to buy,it's worse than YOUTUBE it's in your face 24/7
It's kind of sad and pathetic when the new kid on the block are headlight flares,how about fixing some
of the bugs instead of letting the community do it for you,faster than you!

So in the 30 years Ive been simming,from the 48k spectrum 1984 to present day running a 4Ghz beast,this title is probably the biggest letdown/disappointment experianced over those years.

TOTAL COST OF DLC --------- £2,159.43 ----------

Tads rating on the sim-meter   1/10 - and thats being generous!
voteText: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I read so many NO to recommend votes for TS2014 here on Steam and while I bought this game way back in the RailWorks day, for 75% off and have received the update to 2014, I so wanted to love this game.

And I do like this game, as much as it is possible to like it.

Unfortunately, despite my trying very hard, it takes a lot of overlooking it’s blatantly badly produced software – and I am talking about the latest TS2014, not some previous incarnation.

There are so many game breaking bugs in this game that do not appear to ever have been addressed.

I only own the base content for this game and it is so full of bugs that leave you no option but to completely quit your efforts and start again in the hope that you don’t encounter those issues the next time you try to complete any given scenario.

The game is also very badly optimised. No other title on my computer makes my fans spin up to the torrent of noise that this game achieves only minutes after first launch.

As for the near €2500 worth of DLC, I have never purchased any. I’m just not that brave or stupid. I have read lots of issues still remain in the DLC also which has been reported by the real hardcore fans and the impression is that there is no plan to fix.

Had I not read any such bad DLC reviews, I still would not purchase, for the base game is enough to warn me off.

Such a shame, I would like to really get into this title, but it just doesn’t seem to be worth all the aggravation and lack of support.

Buy or don’t – well, I’m not recommending…

reviewText:
I figured it was on sale, so what the heck.  The game as a simulator itself is good, but I would not recommend the game at the current price it is.  You absolutely need to buy the DLC's in order to enjoy the game to download the routes you want, and they are very expensive, and their sale prices aren't even that good.  The stock game itself is definitely lacking, and you will quickly get tired of stock routes.

All in all, this is definitely a souless train simulator, as it is simply a cash cow for the developers of this game.  They created a base game which was already expensive, and force you to pay just as much for a single add-on that you may want.  In some trains, the sounds are simply reused and the prices are still the same as others.

Dont be fooled by the pretty visuals of this game, I dont recommend it, even if it was on sale.

reviewText:
I have been playing this game since the first rail simulator game in 2007 the game has been good but there is so many bugs that have never been fixed. Even though the game graphics looks ok the AI part of the game isn't that good.

I like building routes in this game which can be hard at first which gets easier and then you start finding the bugs game crashes when you do some complecated junctions etc. Then after building your route you decided i know i will run two trains one user controlled and the other AI. After setting up where your AI train is going to go (on a double track railway) your Ai train decides i can pass that point because the user train is in the way but the train is on the other track and another strange bug. Other things like track floating in mid air sounds on some trains are not good i could go on with a list of bugs. Also on common bug where most you would have seen red lights at a railway crossing the cars sometime drive stright through. The one thing i don't like is they never really fixed the game it was just change the name of the simulator and of course change the company name but made no diffrence.

Above all that some parts of the game is intresting and there is some routes which you have to pay extra round about £25 a route comes with scenery trains. Trains anything from £6 up to £12 The game is good apart really from certain bugs a few years ago yes i would have recommended this game to a friend but there so many new things out now next gen console's and games which is better to spend your money on lots of people would disagree with my comment which is fine but you might enjoy the game or you might not.

Update after relase of trs 2015

Since trs2015 has come out well no bugs have been fixed its just a change of name new weather effects and UI change and thats it still the same basic game as 2012 2014 and 2015 nothing has changed. As for routes they are a bit short some are broken which i have had to fix in the editor the only routes i would say are long and worth it are the GARL routes and western lines of Scotland all other routes are far to short

reviewText:
Not BAD, but no-way would I reccomend this to a friend. This isn't a game, this is the foundations of a game. The basic routes are just boring, and to get any sort of entertainment from this game you need to fork out more and more money for locomotives / scenarios. What happened to the era of giving someone a game, and not part of a game on purchase?

Ontop of that, I'm having some pretty damn awful performance issues. I get frame tearing despite capping the frame rate. Oh, there's also no V-Sync option built into the games settings, WTF? After capping 60FPS in the Catalyst Control Center, my frames still tear. I have a pretty decent system, 3rd gen i5 CPU, R9 280X GPU, 16GB RAM, SSD, etc.. Yet this games also likes to lag all over the place every now and then.

The sad news is that this is the best that Train Simulators get. If you don't mind putting up with all ^those problems, and you don't mind spending the cash, go for it. But it's got problems.... A LOT OF PROBLEMS.

reviewText:
The Steam edition of Train Simulator 2015  is well worth buying, especially when on sale as you can get it as cheap as 80% off.  Each year since its release in June  2009  the game has been upgraded for free (so far); it started life as a game called Rail simulator, but was released on Steam with a name change to Railworks and later became Train Simulator.     If you're a train enthusiast, you'll want to expand the  game  by adding  more dlc; I highly recommend you wait until sales are on to get  most dlc for at least 50% off  or more.  You don't need every dlc to enjoy this game.  It would cost an absolute fortune if you were to buy all or most of the dlc  available, even  when you take account of all the   dlc being on sale; however , to  those of us who enjoy this sort of game, its well worth it.

It is the best  train simulator  available at this time and has been since its release back in 2009. (I don't know what the original Rail Simulator was like).  If you aren't bothered as much about the graphics then the Trainz series is probably the way to go as you get  loads more rolling stock, engines and   different  area's to explore in the  basic package. plus there's only about 10 dlc  available for the game.    I backed the latest version of Trainz via Kickstarter as I thought they were going to make  a much better looking  game this time, but I was wrong.  Engine cab details are appalling compared to the almost life like cabs you find in Train simulator 2015, plus you can use most of the controls  using your mouse, or touch screen. Also you have two ways you can drive your  trains in Train Simulator, either   using the quick drive controls, or  using the actual  controls in the train.  Trainz as far as I can remember doesn't include that option.

Since this game was added to the workshop, there are  masses of extra content available for free. Not all of it will be usable unless you have the appropriate dlc, but you'll still find loads for  the basic  Steam version of the game.

Check out a few videos HERE, HERE, HERE, and HERE. Not the best videos, but I wanted to post  videos without adverts.

reviewText:
I've owned this game for a few years now.
Sadly, it is going downhill fast. Numerous bugs, which have been present for ages, are not being sorted.
The worst is the terrible stutter, that seems to be prevalent, on any resolution!
I've got a GTX 970 and an overclocked i5 4670K processor and it runs poorly. I can run in Nvidia DSR at 1517p and it runs at over 100 frames per second, then bang! Every few seconds it stutters and the frame rate drops into single figures.
Extremely frustrating and makes the game unplayable.
Incidentally it does the same thing at 1080p and is still unplayable.

Such a pity that this company only seem interested in fleecing their loyal fan base with ever increasing amounts of dlc.
What's the point of buying dlc if the core game is so poorly optimised?

If Dovetail can get it sorted then it's worth buying, until it is, avoid like the plague and if you've still bought it, DO NOT buy any extra dlc!

4/10

reviewText:
I heard people who are destroying this game in the review section, so I decided I make a Review

-Pros
-A Decent Map editor
-A easier control system than Rail Simulator

-Cons
-Only a couple of maps and some content to work with
-Overpriced DLC
-No Graphical Update to the game engine
-Horrible Bugs and Crashes
-Overpriced to be a $9-15 Game
-Poorly Optimized Game
-Not Beta Tested Properly

Overall, the game is one of the most horrible game released in Late 2013- Early 2014. The Company who made this had the balls to release an unpolished remake of a game that was released in 2012.
I Highly recommend that you get the original MSTS and its other patches or Trainz Simulator 2012.
Both have free content and have good places to get great Payware content in High Quaility.

Avoid this game at all cost, if you got this game from a friend, sell it or give it to someone else.

Also I refuse to give this game a rating from 1 - 10

-Green
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: An ok game as a newbie to Train simulator its an alright game. Not the best simulator that i've played like MSFS and ETS2 but it is fairly fun. It would be better if some parts of the gameplay was improved like creating senarios etc also improving the scenery. But the main bug I have is prices. I got it on the steam deal this week but normally being 25 pound it seems like an ok price. But soon after playing the sim for a bit you do get a bit bored with the three routes and few trains given. Then you look on the store to see what other routes and trains and the prices aren't good. I mean really 25 pound for a route?? its as much as the game. Definately not good. Also what everyone seems to be saying it's the same as 2013 but with XP. Not pleased but as I have it now I have to deal with it. But apart from those problems it is ok and I think can have potential.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I don't expect a train simulator to be a work of visual art, on par with things like Bioshock or Far Cry.

The graphics?  Uninspired.

The game mechanics?     It's definitely not going to win any awards for fidelity.

But when we (my son and I) manage to pick a switch trying to get something moved in a freight yard.... and watch a passing intermodal train fly off the rails as if picked up by an invisible unrendered tornado?    Yeah, we lost it.     The fact that the game engine allowed something to happen like that?     I'm just done.   I can't take the game seriously anymore.

This is the first game I regret buying.     I'm sorely tempted to ask for a refund, and list The game just sucks" as the reason
date: but I know that's insufficient justification for such actions.\n\nEven at Steam Sale prices I feel cheated
recommended: and I can't see how the developers justify their normal prices for the base game
hoursPlayed: let alone the DLC.\"

reviewText: Great concept, but needs a lot of work. As the other guys said. DLC's are way overpriced. Old ones should be discounted or given for free. They are not even close to the quality of the new ones. New DLC's cost same as single popular game on steam, this is unacceptable. This is an add-on and should be price as much. Bugs, bugs, bugs and more bugs... there is no support or what so ever. After e-mailing support for such a long time all I got is your issue has been forwarded to the support team" and it ends here. I've been complaining and asking for help multiple times about "Northeast corridor" DLC because it is full of bugs and cant even play it. No single issue has been fixed so far and I paid $39.90 for this product. My adventure with Train Sim ends here. Can't fight anymore with people that care only about money and do not fix their problems."

reviewText: Some times game developers do not think about their customer and this game is an example of it. Game is good and have all the features that we can expect from a train sim but developers are charging way more than it deserves. They are selling each DLC at a price of an ordinary game. I have never seen such an aggressive pricing scheme in a game. Before TS 2013, majority of tracks were included in the base game (as done in many Train Sim games) but from TS 2013 they are selling each route as DLC at a hefty price. I also noticed that even during Steam Sales DLC prices do not get much lower as compared to the base game. This is their cheap trick to lure innocent gamers into buying their game. As a game developer your first priority should be your customer's satisfaction but here it looks like their's priority is money. The game which was selling at $50-60 (TS 2012) is now selling at $1500-1700 (including all routes and content).

reviewText:
this game is fun but I have 4 issues with it train wise not game wise , other than that it runs perfectly  :

-  My first issue is the fact that there is a lack effort to combat the many glitches this game encounters , just by adding a new name and textures dosen't mean that the game has improoved it just makes it worse .

-My second issue is about the fact there arn't any undergroun , subway , metro and japanese maglev routes after all it is a train simulator thus meaning it should have many of these challenging high speed routes . until they add these routes and trains then what are we fans like me gonna look forward to the next upcoming year , cos when i play this game it feels like ' train sim 13 ' not 14 .

- My third issue is about the lengths of the route and the route itself  30 or 50 miles ain't gonna cut it especially when we fans are limited to 3 countries 6 or seven would be perfect . the routes should be at most 400miles long and have some sort of danger like fallen powerlines or a train derailment or a tree in the middle to keep us train drivers on edge and some sort of music or sound to keep those newbies awake, afterall it makes the development team more money to develop and us fans entertained .

my fourth and final issue is about the AI , this game has the worst AI ever . its clunky and unrealistic and don't show a visual image when they board a train you can spin , fly , walk and even chang camera and you won't see the AI board your train , its just the same people on the same train . other simulators and games show off their AI boarding busses boaring planes and other vehicles and they look extremely detailed and don't all walk like pimps with that wierd limp .


It is very sad that a simulator of this nature and popularity lacks in these small but very notable problems would have thought by now it would look AMAZING with numerous routes that are at least 0 to 400miles long

reviewText:
Great for the first hour, after which the only way to get any enjoyment is to pick the fastest trains on the smallest networks and try to ram/collide with/run over stuff.

Too many DLCs that you have to buy, no diversity in the game, animations for boarding passengers/cargo is terrible, interaction with the environment is zero and the weather and climate has no diversity whatsoever. Menus also do not function and are confusing - to be honest, they make no sense and titles of each menu does not even suit what the menu gives the options of. They are made with the intention of looking good and nothing else.

Ever since I was really young I loved trains, but this game had potential that it does not meet.

reviewText:
This game is gorgeous, and a very detail rich simulation.  Driving a train and enjoying the scenery is a much slower gaming experience, which isn't a bad thing.

But I can't recommend this because the developer nickle and dimes the customer to death.  Want different engines?  Prepare to pay.  Want more routes?  Pay again.  Want to use an engine that you bought in a route pack on another route?  Guess what.  If I buy an engine with a route, I want to be able to use that in any route in the game.  This just annoys me.

I'm not hardcore enough a train fan to want to pay the $1,000+ they want to charge for all the DLC they offer, and I suspect that most gamers are going to feel the same way.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I played an earlier version of this game and enjoyed it very much, however this version, despite having better graphics, is inferior for many reasons. All load screens are just big ads to buy content from the developer. A link to the dev's site is fine, and I understand paying for DLC, but the content costs more than the base game! Are you kidding me?!? The tutorials for the game stink. There is one for basic controls and one for expert. Both are short and not terribly informative. I've found very little in the way of free content, unlike most other sims, but I just may not be looking hard enough. All-in-all, I wish I could get a refund on this; it wasn't even worth the $8 during the summer sale.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I bought TS-2014 for $8.99 during the Steam Summer Sale inspite of knowing very well of the problems others reviewers had indicated. But boy did not know that TS-2014 was such a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ product. This game is so buggy that it crashed about 4 times in less than an hour of play.  I choose the scenario I want to play, wait for the loading to complete and boom! the entire game crashes. The error message I get is a Unable to write to a dump file" -whatever that sentence means. A very poorly executed game. No wonder so many people are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off after buying this game."
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I bought this game during the Christmas sale in 2013 and was very dissappointed, I eventually out of frustration deleted it from my PC I'm so glad I did not pay full price.
Today I saw the reduced price of 3 DLC's I had really wanted back then but could not afford, they were 50% off in the current sale and I almost bought them but, thought I would first check the Steam forums to see if there were problems / improvements with the 2014 update and I'm glad I did because they reminded me what a purely money driven bunch of bugs this game is plus, there now seems to be more problems and no attempt to solve any of the existing long term bugs.
Look at the specs, they only provide the minimum requirements 2 gig ram 512Mb Graphics card windows XP there is no mention of the ideal set up.
I couldn't play this, it constantly crashed I have a 1gig Gforce gtx 280 card 4 gig ram (32 bit Vista so just over 3 gig usable) and 2.8 quad core processor so, I assumed no problem, WRONG!
I went on the forums and met two attitudes one being, yes there is a long term bug that causes this crashing and it has never been fixed the second presumably from the games company employees or its fans was my PC was not up to the job with less than 4 gig ram which suggests you need to be runnuing 64 bit to fully utilize the software, there is no mention of this in the specs which claim it will run on XP with only 2 gig Ram and a 512 graphics card. If that is not true then the product is being misrepresented however, they are probably using the word RUN in the loosest possible of terms.
I tried turning everything down to minimum but, it still crashed with depressing regularity.
There is a lack of documentation with the game however, it is available, made by the fans fortunately there is a strong fan base that the company in no way deserves a lot of what the developers should be doing is being done by those playing the game.
Most items in the workshop require you to purchase overpriced DLC's to use them because the base game comes with so little.
I found problems with things that did not seem to work as one would expect or were missing entirely such as lights, trackside information provided too late to effectively use, commuters as dumb as ducks.
I could happily ignore all the little things and even inaccurate simulation if the game was as good as it ought to be and indeed could be especially with the available fan base plus, if a second mortgage were not required to purchase DLC's some several years old already, just to make the game more varied challenging and enjoyable to play.
I was going to spend $25.00-$30.00 on DLC's not a lot to some but, a lot to me now, I shall be spending less on something that works as it should and will not require a constant financial input.
I don't object to paid DLC's but, a game should not force you to buy highly priced DLC's just to make it playable, especially  as this game is buggy however, I suppose fixing it is not as lucrative as producing another $20.00 DLC.
The basic game is the bare minumum possible perhaps not even that, in the countries covered there are enough trains new and vintage and miles of track to provide a bigger and more varied starting package and still allow for almost endless DLC's.
The devs claim this pricing strategy is to keep the price down on the base game, I feel it is more give the buyer something so basic they'll eventually spend far more money than they would ever have been initially willing to pay to make it playable, just add up the non-discount cost of the base game and say 4 DLC's you could be well on the way to $100.00 even top games cost less than that and many excellent simulators that also have plentiful DLC's provide far more for less cost in the base game.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Not worth it even with discount, The game is like 1 HUGE info-Commercial, Always trying to sell you stuff in game.
It looks ok on the outside of the train, But in the cab none of the controls have lables, over 2/3 the buttons are just for show.
Does not have a good (or any if you want to call it that) Walk through to understand the countrols, lights, switching of tracks,

I love trains, Just this game is not done well.

Save your money on this one people. I am glad I waited for the sale. I feel a bit ripped off now at $9.00, I can just see if I shelled out the full $75.55 + I got.

STAY AWAY from this game.

reviewText: No one buys this game for fast paced action or head scratching puzzles. I suspect most people, like me, buy this game for the beautiful scenery and calm journeys across the country side. And because it's on sale. And then after the download disappointment sets in. The manual, if there is one, is probably in pdf format and tedious to read so the tutorial is the obvious place to start. But what you're not told is that the first tutorial in the list teaches you how to drive forward, but doesn't tell you you're starting on a hill. So it seems as if the controls don't work. So give up on the tutorial and jump right in and what meets you? Sad, low rez graphics as you travel  through what could be a breathtaking view but are met with scenery from MS Flight Simulator 3. Perhaps Career Mode will be better"
date: you think. Think again. For anywhere from $20 to $40 you have to download an add-on to have a career on. Perhaps the graphics are better on these but since the pics and videos they use to sell the game are way better than what you get I wouldn't blow five times the purchase price of the game to find out."
hoursPlayed: false
helpfulPercent: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I would be able to recommend this game if we had a time machine and could travel back to 2012, which was before the company now known as Dovetail Games removed the majority of content and made it all DLC exclusive. As a result you will have to fork out massive amounts of cash in order to get your moneys worth of the full asking price of $54.99 USD.

The basic game without any DLC comes as barebones as possible and you will almost definitely be looking at which DLC you fancy within an hour or two, and of course having you to spend much more than the already ridiculous base price of $54.99 USD.

Aside from the DLC issue, there are two other blatant problems that have not been addressed by the developer. The first is the unrealistic acceleration and braking, which makes this simulator feel much more like an arcade game. The second issue is that you will be left asking where your money's worth is going with the numerous DLC you will undoubtly purchase since the developers rarely patch or update any routes or locomotives that have bugs. You will see cars driving in the air for example, alongside the road.

Since I've bought over 50 different DLC routes and locomotive packs my copy of the game actually has a decent amount of content, but since I've had to spend tenfold on this game as I have on any other; it is simply impossible to recommend it. That said, having spent hundreds of hours on this game I can say that it is enjoyable if you have an interest in trains or trainspotting.

reviewText:
As an individual who has played this game for *sigh* 2,000 hours, I'm going to go very in depth,  and list what I can about this game, and what you should consider if buying.

What is TS? If you're familiar with the game, skip this paragraph. Train Simulator has two main features: Driving and building. For driving, you can play various scenarios, or pick a train and roam freely. In the builder, you can build routes from scratch, or edit existing ones, as well as create scenarios. What you make can be uploaded for others to play.

Right then, you know what this game is about. Now I assume you're interested in the game, otherwise why are you here?
First pro/con. Lot's of people will tell you that the DLC is way too overpriced. Agreed. If you can, wait for a sale. But since we're on the topic, there's loads of different DLC's to choose from, all of various regions and countries. American? German? There's something there you may like.

Next pro/con. Almost equal to the DLC complaints are the graphical complaints. You must have a very good graphics card and a fast computer if your picky about looks. You're missing out on a lot without highest graphics settings, such as rain drops on windows, and visible light reflections. Detail on locomotives and freight cars is great (with high graphics settings) and getting better. Sounds are kinda meh, but are also improving.

Another pro/con. Bugs are of course evident. In what game are they not? If you experience a problem, ask the community, or e-mail Dovetail Game's support team. They show up a fair bit, and chances are, you're not the first to experience it.

Final pro/con. It's not mentioned that often, but I think it should be. The builder, where I spend most of my time, is very detailed. Practically anything DTG can do, you can do as well. Edit the terrain, place assets from bought DLC, lay track, roads, rivers, fences. You can do practically anything. There's even a Google Maps integration, allowing you to see what things look like at your coordinates, and making it easier to copy a route.

Wow, I've written a novel. So that's what to expect in TS2016. I'll let you decide whether or not it's a good game. We all have different opinions.
Do you think I left something important out? Please let me know!

reviewText:
How could I play a sim for so long and advise against purchase, may you ask?
The reason is simple: the graphics and the atmosphere are great, the route editor is amazingly efficient when you know the ropes. As a world building tool, TS is the best sim in town. But...

... I cannot say the same of the activities. The AI is appalling, the replayability of the scenarios is close to zero. TS2014 added the notion of QuickDriving: the concept is great, but the implementation is spoiled. There is SOME degree of unpredictability, but 99.99% of the time the next signal ahead will be dumb green. The only randomness that adds fun to the driving is the traffic on the other lanes.

reviewText:
This game claims to be the ultimate train table train simulator.  By this I mean it advertises itself as being the ultimate digital model railroad software.

Sadly, it is not.

It fails to be a decent simulator, it fails to be a decent layout builder game, and it fails to be a decent game in general.

In real life, if you build a layout, you can at least know, when you buy new rolling stock, if it's the right scale and the correct gauge, you can run it on your layout.

Not so in Train Simulator.  There's a convoluted path to putting your new rolling stock on to the train table.

But you're discounting free ride mode."  No
recommended: because there's nothing immersive about driving a single train through a dead world with no other train but yours in it.  That's just dull and lifeless.\n\nOne of the so-called advantages this game offers is the ability "to build a virtual layout."  Unfortunately
hoursPlayed: that's not as easy as they make it out to be
voteText: either.\n\nCities In Motion 2
helpfulPercent: Train Fever
votesHelpful: and Euro Truck Simulator 2 have much easier
votesTotal: more intuitive "world builder" tools than this game does.  And this is bad because:  Train Fever only generates random maps for you to play on; Cities In Motion 2 really isn't a builder game
votesFunny: either; and Euro Truck Simulator 2 not only has to be reconfigured to access the map building tools
commentsCount: but is not sold on the strength of a user's ability to create new worlds!\n\nAs far as simulation?  While Train Fever currently lacks many simulation features
column16: it still far superior in the simulation department than this game is - in spite of any ability to drive the vehicles - merely because they make the world feel "alive."  The same holds true with Cities In Motion 2
column17: what with it's chronic traffic problems and what not.  And the Euro Truck Simulator 2 simulation is actually more forgiving than the simulation in this game.\n\nWe can all agree
column18: for instance
column19: in real life
column20: driving a train past a red signal is generally bad.  But there are conditions under which - even without dispatcher approval! - most railroads won't really object.  Specifically:  If you're not actually blocking other tracks!  Specifically
column21: if one stops a foot or two too late in this game
column22: it's enough to end the scenario.  I'm pretty sure real railroads don't work like that!\n\nIn Euro Truck Simulator 2
column23: you can sort of get away with things that would force a real life driver off the road
column24: but it's a compromise
column25: since alot of times
column26: the world feels much less predictable (although it's really more predictable
column27:
once you learn it) than real life.

Which brings me to general game play.

I bought a Cab Forward for this game.  Beautiful model.  Beautiful locomotive.  But I can only drive it in two redneck-themed scenarios?  I can't challenge the Cajon Pass with such a beautiful machine - at least
column28: not easily?  Wasn't the point of allowing me to buy this to give me more content to enjoy?  I have "The Empire Builder
column29:
which any rail fan recognizes as pretty much the standard configuration of any long distance Amtrak train.  Why can't I run that through something in the Cajon Pass without great difficulty?  Why is it easier to enjoy the new content in ETS2, Train Fever, and Cities In Motion 2 than in Train Simulator?

In short, this game just plain fails.

It has huge potential, but all that promise leads to horrible disappointment.

I can not recommend this game.

reviewText:
I'm sorry but this game is utter garbage, and it's NOT worth the money !!

-Short version:
The game looks ok, feels more like an arcade that a simulator (which i kind of like), has a nice concept, but is completely unoptimised! It crashes randomly, has major lag spikes and overall feels like an unfinished product rushed for a release. The devs need to make either a major update to it, or make sure TS2015 isn't anything like this game is (which I doubt, considering what I constantly read about this game)

-Long version:
I bought the game on the summer sale, since I had kept an eye on it for quite some time, and even though I have ~60h of playtime at the time of writing this, I actually have more that 200h of playtime but not on my steam account. Anyway, I bought it mainly because of the editor - the whole google maps overlay, the SRTM terrain data you can use and the tools the editor has alow to make incredibly accurate routes with overall very good detail. That is if the game didn't crash randomly so often. I have lost hours of content due to it not being saved and the game crashing. To counter this I started saving my route every 20-40minutes, but today, after the 4th or 5th crash for the day of the game all my layout's track had disappeared, which made me absolutely mad. Hours of my work was gone! Now, before someone says I'm doing a rage review" or something I want to say that that was just the tip of the iceberg

What I find most annoying is the pricing of DLC and the game itself. Sure £40 is to be expected of a new game but to repeat that same charge EVERY year just so you can use the next version, don't you think they should perhaps give you a discount if you already own a version of the game, instead of making us pay another £40 just to unlock the new stuff where someone new gets everything (I don't know that fully but I have not tested this). For DLC I would expect either pennies for the cost of whats in the DLC or at that price, more from the DLC.

I will only keep playing the game till I have racked up enough hours I think to have recieved my moneys worth but in other words I am really dissapointed with this game.

Another point. Yes this game does do very well to amaze us with the graphics of their locomotives... but that is it. If you go into Free-Roam camera view and stray more than 5 metres away from the track, you will find a terribly under textured enviornment that is plain and boring. I would expect much more from a simulator as I do not just expect the experience of the train very good but everything around it to make the mise-en-scene.

reviewText:
This is actually very old game engine without much 2014 glory in it. Did not meet my expectations even remotely.

During initial launch of the game graphics were flashing in the main menu already and game resolution wasn't the one specified in the options. After 15 minutes of diagnostics I figured that this game seems to work properly only in windowized mode with my setup.

Once in game I quickly realized that train controls are horrible. Levers are difficult to control accurately with mouse and keyboard controls are total joke. Options contained support for gamepad but surpricingly my gamepad (dualshock) didn't fly... After diagnostics and some googling I found outdated unnofficial analog gamepad plugin to use. Installed that and got my gamepad working somehow, but even that requires running external application behind the actual game and in the end really doesn't save the games poorly designed user interface.

The content of this game is very limited and they clearly want you to buy DLC to upgrade right away. Career mode is more or less a joke and I don't really feel like spending much more time with this game (even I do like trains).

Note to self: next time when you feel like buying something, read the steam reviews/forums and believe what people say.

Thankfully I paid only few euros from this during summersale 2014. Paying full price would had caused some real tears .)

If you want good transport simulator with much more bang for the buck, forget this and get Eurotruck Simulator II instead.

reviewText:
Terrible optimisation, combined with outrageous prices for DLC and lack of quality control makes this game a technical disaster. Best train simulator around, but my god, what a low bar that is.

++ In-house route editor is nice

+ Sound effects are quite good on some trains

~ Workshop only works with add-on content packs (which costs €5/piece)

- Poor optimisation on all systems
- Route editor has no explanation whatsoever
- Textures are terrible
- Re-used assets while DLC costs a bloody fortune
- DLC prices

-- Extreme long-lasting loading screens
-- Random crashes without warning (dump-errors?)
-- Patches are rarely fixing anything before making more bugs
-- Content of each year must be bought seperatly


Final conclusion
A: Must-have, fantastic game with little to no flaws
B: Buy it in a sale, great game if you can get it for a discount
C: Okay game, buy it in a sale if you like what you see
D: Not worth a buy, too many loose ends, bugs or terrible gameplay
E: Technical mess, do not buy, buyer beware

- Too expensive ( I bought it for 6,99€ ) Normal price 34,99€
- Bad support
- Too expensive DLC's  ( Omg 4000€ for all. You are kidding me?)

TS 2016 is normally a wonderful game, but the big
problem is the DLC politics. Why so expensive?
Now i have not a DLC. I play with the normal content, but its boring.
I dont recommend this game!!!

reviewText:
I do love parts of this game even though this isn't really a 100% simulator. The content creation is good, I like building my own layouts, and the pre-made ones scenarios and such look really good. I still would not recommend this game if you are a die hard solid 200% rail simulator fan looking for the most realistic sim out there, its more for the casual train enthusiast & creator. The creation options are tricky but they are learnt through practice.

Now we come to the deal with MONEY!! I personally got this game in the winter sale, with add-ons, in the limited period for £6:29p so I cant complain about that price!!!! but the normal RRP and the price of the DLC content is WAY WAY WAY overpriced, its borderline insanity, train packs should be 99p not over £10 in some cases, its just too much for add-ons.

Money and content pricing... 1 / 10
Simulation realism... 6 / 10
Creation and building layout fun... 8 / 10.
That's my take on it anyway.

reviewText:
Very disappointed in Train Simulator 2015 since Windows 10 was installed on my computer.  Cannot play the game at all.  Contacted TS 2015 support and was told the problem was being worked on.  Game will not load.  On inital screen when it gets to--TS2015-V52.2A Updating Scenario Database--everything freezes up and cannot do anything.   By using control-alt-delete to get to task manager I get a message--Saved dump file to 'C:TempDump\TS2015-V52.2A.dmp' .   After that get a message that Rail Works exe.  has stopped working and will close program.

Things worked fine until Windows 10 was installed so have to be suspicious of that system.

In any case, at this point could not recommend the game to anyone until DoveTail comes up with a solution to this problem.
