reviewText:
I am not one who normally writes a review. I recently grabbed MSTS from the shelf it has sat on for over 10 years. I bought it and never used it. I found it to be fun and an enjoyable break from sim racing. My wife wanted to get Train Simulator 2014 for me so I would have something that worked better and could add content to easier.

What a mistake this has been. One of the tutorial missions/ task running the 395 high speed train I have never gotten it to work. I ALWAYS fail at the end. I even got a video from YouTube and the guy that posted it said that he usally fails that task as well. He also said that TS 2014 was VERY buggy. I had heard that before purchasing as well but chalked it up to the usual gripping that I found so often in forums. I should have listened. The problem with the 395 train was just the beginning.

I tried, and just completed a career job, and not only failed it didn't really give me any possibility of not failing. The train coming down from Donner Pass would just take off even though I'm on the brakes. The dynamic brakes don't work. Go ahead and apply them, you will only speed up. They did it in MSTS and they do it here as well.

The bottom line is this. Unless you just have to have this title, OR you just HAVE to run a train simulator save your money and go and get a different game. I was going to add in quite a bit of extras during the Steam Summer Sale that is going on now until June 30, 2014, that will not be happening now. I guess I'll just take the money and go and get some more stuff for FSX or more sim racing equipment. There is a lot of gear from Fanatec that I wanted to get.

reviewText: This game is absolutely amazing. The five minute loading screens are such a great aspect because it allows you to become moist and wet for the trains. And when the trains arrive, it's like the pope rose from the grave and gave everyone high-fives. The gameplay is absolutely amazing, the simple mode is a little easy, so Expert is where this game really shines. The expert mode uses three levers, movement, direction, and brake and it also comes with an amazing usage of nine camera angles. That's right, NINE CAMERA ANGLES. WHERE DO THEY EVEN HAVE TIME TO PROGRAM ALL THESE ANGLES?! The anti-piracy script put into the game during the loading screens is honestly needed, a game such as this needs to be protected from those nasty pirates that try to ruin game businesses with their cheap ways. Waiting three extra minutes per loading screen for a two minute gameplay is a small price to pay to make sure the pirates don't steal an amazing game such as this. Have I mentioned the graphics? 11/10 GOTY

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings for this game. I want to be in love with it,but I just can't no matter how hard I try. Although the game looks amazing and the selection of trains is rather good,there are just too many things wrong with it. First,all the missions are SUPER picky. You could have a 100% perfect scenario and only make one little mistake,and the game forces you to try again if you want to truly complete it. Also,the train controls are weird and it never seems that your train can hold a constant speed,which makes it difficult to maintain speed limits.

But by far the biggest problem with the game is DLC. Oh. My. God. This game is upwards of $60,so you would think you would get an exstensive amount of content included,right? Wrong. You get only a few trains and routes,and you have to pay for everything else. Which would be fine...if it wasn't so damn expensive! Most DLC is priced between $20-40,and the fact that I have to pay that much for one thing after I've already payed quite a bit for the game is absurd. This is the main killing factor for me and it prevents from enjoying Train Simulator as much as I could.

Don't get this game. If your looking for a good train simulation game,try the Trainz series. All of them are fun,have loads of content right out of the box,have free community created DLC,and are a one time purchase. Maybe if my problems with the game were resolved,it wouldn't be so bad. But for now,I stand by my opinion strongly.

reviewText:
I grew up playing Southern Belle on the C64 and I remember when MS Train Simulator was released and I imported it from America to the UK to play it on\close to release date (where it was released in America before the UK).

For me the biggest problem with this game is it does not fully support the Raildriver Train Controller and only half the trains I have work properly with it. The company which makes raildriver acknowledges the issues and hopes this game will be better supported in future releases, but also recommends a competing train simulator which does have full native support built in for Raildriver (perhaps thats why native support is not included with this game, which is a huge shame). The company who create Train Simulator just ignore you and the entire rest of the people who buys this game and its add ons it seems.

The game is buggy to say the least and some of the official routes are supplied with scenarios that just don't work or were created for earlier versions of Train Simulator and have been broken in later version with no fixes or updates. For example I bought GEML London to Ipswich - two of the supplied scenarios do not include the needed trains to play the route and at some stations passengers are walking inside the platform. Some platforms are not long enough to fit all carriages of 12 car trains and many of the branch lines on the route have not been included. Many of the free scenarios on the workshop require you to purchase other routes and trains, and for buggy and broken content the game DLC is far too overpriced with some routes costing the same as the game costs, and items rarely appear in steam sales. Every so often you will find mis-matched bundles including a route and a train which includes scenarios designed for a different route - A very cheeky way to encourage people to then buy more trains which contain scenarios for the route they have just bought and the route for the train they have just bought.

Compared to modern games the engine is beginning to look slightly dated as well, but instead of spending time on improving these (I read somewhere the next version will have big improvements to the skies!) the developer should listen to the community and its players and fix broken scenarios and known bugs. I am sure the game has lost fans and community due to its flaws and them being ignored, which is a shame for everyone.

There is another 3rd company creating routes for this game which they are listening to feedback and creating fixes for their products, so I am going to try a few of them.

I's buy this in a sale if you like this kind of a simulator, but only pay full price if you really love train simulation and are prepered for the issues.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Rather than inovate or bring any real changes to the series, Dovetail is more interested in making minor cosmetic changes as well as possibly a few gimmiks. They are most interested in making money at the expense of their fan base. I have never enountered a worse developer in my entire life. Rather than make the game interesting, they make the game so bare bones as to force you to purchase the rediculously priced DLC. Instead of spending time making a great game, they spend time making constant payware. Now they may say they don't expect you to buy the $8000 worth of DLC, but they make the game so within playing it a few times it gets repetive. You're basically paying for an engine and interface and then if you want to use it you have to pay for addons that cost as much or more than most games on Steam. I have never played a game, even from EA, where DLC is more mandatory. It's like paying $50 for a free to play game. The new DLC is on the loading screens and just makes you feel like you have to buy it. I don't  understand how Steam allowes this. I mean have they turned into someone like Microsoft or Sony. Valve was always supposed to be the company that cared about gamers, not just their money. The have really dropped the ball here, letting Dovetail release the same game every year and turn out DLC constantly. To make this game enjoyable, you will have to buy thousands of dollars of DLC. Nothing is included in the game, it's all extra.

reviewText: The main game is ok, if you like trains.  There's not really that much to do....drive the train from point A to point B, but that's sort of what you expect in a train simulator.  The main reason I can't recommend this game, though, is because of the DLC.  Oh, the DLC.  I'm writing this during the 2014 Steam Summer Sale, when the game is on special, so all the DLC is deeply discounted.  To buy it all would still cost you $1698.  This isn't the only game to attempt to milk the players through DLC, of course, but it surely must be the most egregious.

reviewText: Rather than inovate or bring any real changes to the series, Dovetail is more interested in making minor cosmetic changes as well as possibly a few gimmiks. They are most interested in making money at the expense of their fan base. I have never enountered a worse developer in my entire life. Rather than make the game interesting, they make the game so bare bones as to force you to purchase the rediculously priced DLC. Instead of spending time making a great game, they spend time making constant payware. Now they may say they don't expect you to buy the $8000 worth of DLC, but they make the game so within playing it a few times it gets repetive. You're basically paying for an engine and interface and then if you want to use it you have to pay for addons that cost as much or more than most games on Steam. I have never played a game, even from EA, where DLC is more mandatory. It's like paying $50 for a free to play game. The new DLC is on the loading screens and just makes you feel like you have to buy it. I don't  understand how Steam allowes this. I mean have they turned into someone like Microsoft or Sony. Valve was always supposed to be the company that cared about gamers, not just their money. The have really dropped the ball here, letting Dovetail release the same game every year and turn out DLC constantly. To make this game enjoyable, you will have to buy thousands of dollars of DLC. Nothing is included in the game, it's all extra.

reviewText:
DON'T BUY THIS GAME UNLESS YOU HATE MONEY

The overall gameplay it's actually fairly good, not superb simulation but it's playable and fun for a while.

The annoying part is the extreme level of DLC, while this can be good, in this case it's just money grabbing.

The base game comes with a few trains, a few routes and a few scenerios. If you want to actually have fun then you need to have a decent level of disposable income or your are planning to declare yourself bankrupt soon and more debt is not a worry.

reviewText:
If you are one of those guys who wants to make his own route then do yourself a favor, never, EVER, buy this game. This game crashed 3 times on me while making 1 real route and 2 fictional routes. In my case I lost over 230+ hours of work.

Also a point of issue is the fact that this game loads more then you ever wish for. You need to have a lot of free time to just play this game. From the mainscreen to the track you selected to drive will cost you at least 1,5 to 2 minutes (if not more).

And lets talk about the standard content of the game. What you get with the game are 3 routes and 5 trains, a bit unfair for the price you paid ain't it? Which brings me to the DLC's. To get all the DLC's for this game, you can pay over $2000, &$^&%$&^#%@#$*(& INSANE.

Don't support these ^*%$&*^$^%#$@%^&holes who let you pay top dollar for a game with so much bugs. Bug Simulator 2014 was a better name for this game.

reviewText: Great Train Driving simulator. It's a lot of fun until you need some new routes or a particular train. reviewText:
Dostoevsky, in his grand work 'The Brothers Karamazov,' had a scene where a man comes out of a pub and fills his cart with drunkards.  His poor horse, who cannot lift the weight of the people, collapses.  The drunkard owner goes on to flog his horse to death, much to the entertainment of the drunken publicans on the cart.  They cheer him on as he whips, beats and curses the dying animal until it collapses and dies, straining to the bitter end.

It is a difficult, unpleasant, indeed horrific scene to read.  But it is as nowhere near as shocking as watching Dovetail flog this dead horse.

This poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ should have been put down years ago, but it keeps coming back from the dead, uglier and more pathetic then ever.  Year on year Dovetail squats down and pinches off the same old turd, almost apologetically, shamefaced with cap-in-hand.  Each year it charges the same exorbitant price for its ropey addons.

The difference between Dostoevsky was that, despite the 'Brothers Karamazov' being a work of fiction, there was an element of real-world grit to it.  You could almost believe it was real.  There's nothing convincing or realistic about Train Simulator 2016,

Its probably time to put a bullet in the skull of this poor animal.  Let it die in peace.

reviewText:
I was lucky in that I bought this game when it was owned by Railworks. Back then the game worked very well, or at least I never ran into any issues with the game.
Unfortunately TS has had the misfortune of being bought by a company that is all about breaking games and charging people for those broken games. Now, a lot of career scenario's, especially the older ones and the ones that come with the base game, are not possible to complete satisfactorily. Scheduling is unrealistic now so that even if you can control your speed to minute precision, it's impossible not to run later and later as the scenario's progress.
If you want a hideous reputation for timekeeping and an occasional speeding penalty because the overlay doesn't accurately display the speed limits, then this is the game for you.
If, however, you want a realistic train simulator that you don't have to treat like a real life Formula One on tracks, wait until another Rail Simulator is released, hopefully by a company that has an interest in the railway experience, and take your chance with that.

reviewText:
I like this game. Decent graphics, good gameplay if you like trains.. alot.
Why am i giving this a thumbs down? The lack of content with the base game.
I bought the base game for about $40 expecting a quality game with plenty of content to play with. What did i get with this game? Some bread crumbs and a raw peice of meat. The game comes with 3 maybe 4 maps to drive around on, i was so disgusted with this game i refuse to play it now so i cant be quite sure how many maps.
Engines. I expected this game would have a good selection of enigines to explore but i was left in shock with the EXTREMELY limited content.

Do you know how to get more engines and maps to play on? Oh its very simple, DLC DLC DLC!!! but what is so bad about a little DLC? what is wrong with it is the fact just one engine add on COSTS $20 #%$@ING DOLLARS!? WHO IN HELL WANTS TO LAY OUT THAT KIND OF MONEY TO DRIVE ONE TRAIN?!?!?

Well, maybe you think it is worth it, okay fine. BUT answer me this, how do you feel about laying out $1,889.15 in money just to enjoy all the features that another game will give you for the cost of less than $60? Yes, that is one thousand, eight hundred eighty nine dollars and fifteen cents for all dlcs for this game. Oh let me be clear this price was posted during the holiday sale when ALL dlcs are half off or more.

Wait, what is that other train game you are talking about? That other game is Trainz simulator 12. Actually ANY game in that series is better than the cost of this. MANY More engines, more maps and the ability to create your very own train setup for much much much much much much much much much much much much less then this game. Save your sanity and your money and screw this game and go buy TRAINZ simulator.

reviewText:
This game is a complete ripoff, sadly it didn't start that way.

At first I posted a positve review for this game. I am now changing to negitive.  I got this game back round 2013 and it was a pretty fair game back then.

Last time I tried to play i had to verify the files something you may end up doing a lot. You would think with all the updates to the game it would run great. However each year they add new content and for what ever reason older content just don't work right.  Dovetail games, has killed this game for me. They only seem to be concerned with making new dlc's to make more money instead of fixing the ones they have already.

It was the 2016 update that broke it bad nuff for my dlc's to not completely function as they once had. I now have textures that will not show up, some trains are not even drivable. As well some scenarios can not be completed with out failing.

If you want to drive trains and don't care about how real it is or if you can complete the scenarios or not. This maybe for you. If you dont mind spending a ton of money on the game.

I have over a grand in this game atm and wish all parts of it would work, but it does not.

It really feels like Dovetail dosn't care so long as they get paid.

As for me, I will be looking into getting a train sim called Run8.

Buy at your own risk.

reviewText:
I expected so much moreI was chasing this game for over a year. When I finally got it I was so happy. But then the horror started. Took ICE-T for a spin and I noticed it's way more bugged than it was in TS 2012. I switched to High-Speed train in UK. It was very good ride, finished scenario with Silver star. Tried another one, scenario is bugged. Thinking it's one time thing, i restarted game and tried again, same thing happened. Checking forum I saw that it's known bug but nobody is fixing it. Eventually I got stuck with only one scenery I like. At last I deleted game. Two days ago, after few months, I installed it again. I immediately remembered why I uninstalled it in the first place. I was more flexible this time, I gave chance sceneries that didn't amuse me at the begining. I took one route in Germany with DB train. Out of sudden -1800 penalty points for speeding! And limit wasn't even marked. It allowed me to go 140 and invisible limit was 60. Tried another one with Acela Express, train derailed due to intersection changed while I was passing. This is absurd. Don't buy it. I regret it.


Perfect description of Dovetail Games thinking:https://i.imgflip.com/o6ykl.jpg

reviewText:
I enjoy simulators, so I bought this during Xmas sale for $8 just to add to my collection.  I had heard some negative ratings, but decided to add to my library anyways.  But I was pleasantly surprised with this excellent simulator!

I never realized driving a train could be so much fun!

Pros:
- Excellent Scenery and Expertly Modeled Trains
- Challenging Tutorials and Career Missions
- Well designed GUI and Simulation Engine
- Learn much interesting facts about trains and their operation


Cons:
- Add-on DLCs are overpriced
- Took over a year to fix Pacific Surliner Addon

reviewText: I have been using Train Simulator back since the original was release by Microsoft.  Many reviewers have voiced various complaints concerning physics, various content (sounds) and DLC costs.  I can understand purists with the dynamics and sounds, which I can take issue with as well, but with DLC, that is an individual choice. The basic game gives us different Country systems to try, and the DLC adds to that enjoyment. However, no one says you have to purchase EVERYTHING. I am from the US and only purchase items that interest me, mostly American units and routes , although a couple of others that look interesting. Folks from other countries I would imagine do the same, so the argument the the DLC is outrageously expensive is subjective to those that want everything in thier collection. The only concession is the reskinning charges which should be minimal or provided as an update to already purchased items.\nI am not so much a hard core player as a casual player, so with that being said, I do like Train Simulator enough to upgrade my computer when necessary. I found no faults with casual railroading, and since space limited me to not have a model railroad, this is the next bext thing, and better in some areas.\nTrain Simulator is enjoyable and a great pasttime,  if you enjoy railroading. Thanks to the Dovetail folks for providing a very pleasant way to spend some hours.

reviewText:
I have been playing Train sims since Maszyna had been released (poland sim). As I am rail fan and had a chance to drive real locomotives, my expectations from simulator are high. Especially, if I paid 40 euros...
Well, there is significant improvement since first Microsoft Train simulator of course. Especially in terms of visuals. BUT, it seems that authors keep building their overpriced DLC on obsolete engine core. And I am not talking about graphics engine now. I am talking about sim core which is 32 bit, however, it seems it's using all my four CPU cores... Essential is, that despite my dream setup ( core i7 2770K 4,5 GHz, 16 GB RAM, game running on very fast SSD Samsung 840 PRO in RAID!) game's stable fps is constantly being interrupted by stuttering as new tile scenery is loaded. I realize that it's not very possible to load whole route into RAM (I have even tried this with RAMDISK -DID NOT HELP) but this is simulator right? So I would expect to tune core first and not to lure customers on new tracks and impressive screenshots.
Another fail are passengers on platforms. The way they move and they behave. Are you serious? After all these years of development they still behave like zombies floating over ground.
Please, make this game proper simulator, otherwise I'll keep feeling like another idiot who fell for pretty screenshots...

PROS: Garmisch and Peterborough are nice routes, Superelevatioon, Some audio improvement
CONS: Totally bad core engine preventing game from running fluid, passengers

reviewText:
I had this game since I had bought the Big Picture Pack of Train Simulator 2013. It is not a bad game as many people would disagree because the price of DLC but you don't need all that DLC to play this. It is cheaper than buying a real model railroad set which is more expensive than the DLCs in this game. Some of the DLCs may sound terrible or the physics messed up. The controls are the same as MSTS (Microsoft Train Simulator) which is why I like this game.

Most of the DLC prices like for example that the locos would cost you a good $20 like the P42DC, Acela Express, and the Union Pacific Big Boy. Routes would cost you a good $40 like the Weardale & Teesdale Network, North Jersey Coast Line, Marias Pass, and Soldier Summit. There's a lot of DLCs to choose from that you may want to get like Steam engines, maybe you want to drive some freight American trains, or a drive a UK passenger train. The DLCs are mostly focused on UK, Germany, and USA but there's third party DLC on Steam that there's routes outside those 3 countries you could get. Steam hosts sales for this game from time to time so you could wait to buy a add-on if you're on budget and buying the DLCs like in bundles would help too.

PROS:
Routes and locos are made from there actual aspects.
Lots of add-ons to choose from.
Good Visuals for an Old Game Engine
Supports TrackIR and RailDriver
Helpful Community
A lot of things to do such as Rail Fanning, operate a Switcher, Freight Train, or a Passenger Train.

CONS:
Lack of Bug Fixing
Content with a lot of bugs, missing speed limits on the HUD on certain routes.
Needs more advanced features while operating a loco.
The DLC's are overpiced
You could get into a #rekt stiulation where your loco can derail, game will end if on a passenger train and then you get thrown a game over message stating that the doors are still open after the loading is done, or running out of water on a steam loco when in a good amount.
Most DLCs would only come with a few scenarios but there's scenarios you can download from the workshop to explore more of the particular route or loco.

reviewText:
Just dont. Remember the days of MSTS and Trainz, fun right. This is a sub standard game at a beyond premium price. A cash cow. I hope all involved starve and get cancer. Go on, kill yourselves you greedy slimy ♥♥♥♥♥♥s!

EDIT/Clarification: (12 of 21 found it helpful prior to this next bit)
This game is really Railworks, very little has changed since 2009.The basic bundled content has not been improved, only year on year they will bundle a couple of different locos with matching stock and a route. The main problem with this is again its not improved. At all! Plants are 2D and follow facing you as you go past, enter a tunnel and a mear shadow is cast.Smoke is unaffected by a bridge, it just floats through the texture. This is all very very outdated, early 2000s stuff.
The world has moved on a lot, it's simply unacceptable for this price.

Secondly, considering the poor quality of the game with its ancient engine. It is not fair to charge per single DLC, as they are basic, at that price. I stress that not long ago at all we had modding communitys making anything and everything at a incredibly reasonable monthly subscriptions, this was dial-up days. A lot was on par with what this game is selling as DLCs. Its a locked eco system. And when they do update the game engine or finally write one worth the price tag all of these DLCs will be worthless.

The developers have you by the balls, and mark my words unless they intend to just rebrand this forever, your £10 per train route whatever is going to be worthless and you will need to start again. The game is far from a product, but while people have a passion and money to burn I guess they are sitting happy at the expense of us.

765,611 people own this game, they have 709 DLCs, profiteering is not the word!

reviewText:
Ok, so I just recently purchased this game after watching the Youtuber DaSquirrelsNuts play this and at that time it looked absolutely brilliant.  Excited, I quickly purchased, installed and started playing. Initially, it was all well, until the next morning, after rebooting my computer the checkmarks for my career was missing. The points and XP were still there, so does the badge you collect as you drive more trains, but with the missing checkmarks, it's hard to keep track of which scenario you've had and hadn't done yet! So I skimped over that small blunder, assuring myself that it's an unimportant non gameplay intruding problem, and oh boy was I wrong.

So on the second day, as I was playing in career mode in a Class 801 (Scenario: The 801 at 8:01), the game started out fine, but my nightmare began once I've reached a red light in Welwyn Garden City Down Fast (opening up the maps indicated an unpowered Class 365 on the tracks). So I waited, and waited (all while spamming the TAB key to request permission to pass) until roughly 30 minutes of waiting before I got the permission to pass. So I told myself, all should be fine now, and I was wrong, again!. Due to this massive delay with the red lights, the timeliness penalty I had was approximately -109000 (can't quite remember the exact figure). Again I told myself, maybe there shall be a big sum of bonus points near the end to neutralize this blunder, so I pushed ahead.

So as the train was thundering to it's final stop, the lights were all green with a breathtaking scenery to sooth my rage, all is once more well in the world of TS2015. Until suddenly, right on my tracks, slowy emerging from the foggy snowy weather was a stationary Class 365.  As I was sitting there, the train approaching it's inevitable end, I pondered, WHAT THE HELL IS WRONG WITH THIS GAME!!!! There was no warning from the lights nor the AWS system! The lights were all green for goodness' sake!

Get this game at your own risk honestly, I do have the save file for the 801 mission stated in this review if you think I was pulling you leg. Dovetail, GET YOUR S**T TOGETHER!!!!

reviewText: At first I thought I was going to like this game as I was going through all the training for all the different types of trains. (Even if load times are slow by todays standards). I started playing the missions in the career mode, the short ones as 1 second in game is one second in real life. I never found a way to fast forward so most of the missions just get boring and repetitive.\nHowever what is forcing me to write this review is the poor design of these missions in terms of letting the user know when speed limits are changing. I was just playing a mission where the speed was 160 (mph I think) and I had 10 minutes until the next station. So I am crusing along enjoying the view as I see no flags (there is a minimap below your controls to let you know when signals or speed changes occur) for miles. then out of the blue the speed dropped to 60, no warning, no signs nothing (I even repeated the mission to check this...still nothing). And once youre speeding (160 in a 60 is serious) you basically loose a ton of whatever points the game is giving you per second (or something) of speeding. So on a mission where I could probably only get 800 points total if I was on time or early to the stations, I am instead loosing 1000+ while trying to get the train down from 160 to 60.\nIt is a total drag when this happens especially after playing the mission for 20+ minutes. I regret buying this game and wish I could recieve a refund.

reviewText:
Brought this game as the screenshots and videos seemed to do it justice...but no, sorry they didn't.

I'm so glad steam started doing the refund option! Because I would be gutted and so dissapointed with the purchase otherwise and it would not get played. I did give it a chance however (clocked 4 hours of gameplay most of that spent on the loading screen)

The actually gameplay was okay, and the graphics were good but.. there was something missing. If you are a true train enthusiast this would appeal to you highly, but I like simulators but really didn't like this one found it very slow and  boring.

Took ages for the game to actually load I must of waited 10 mins and still did not load (and no, its not the hardware in my computer), on top of that extremely annoying music on the load screen. Not the biggest issue but one of the nigly annoying ones, as well as I didn't like the fact that there were ads for Steam on the loading screens.

You also rely heavily on the mouse at first, the tutorials never mention a keyboard alternative, Only until the point I actually looked at the controls and saw that you could use the keyboard this would of made the game even worse.

So to conclude unless you are a massive train fan, and can overlook all that is mentioned above. I wouldn't recommend this title I'm afraid.

reviewText:
While the game can be fun and satisfying, there are issues on some DLC that ruin it:
- trains tilting the wrong way in corners
- wrong displayed speed limit (25 mph allowed, but fined when over 20 mph)
- no tutorials for special systems like cruise control, SIFA, LZB, PZB90, ... (only mentioned in the manual)
- FPS drops
- glitches like signals remaining red or even AI trains getting stuck.
- unachievable or too easy schedules (sometimes you can be 5 minutes early, sometimes you will be late, not matter what)
- no keyboard rebindings

These bugs are in the standard game career scenarios for more than a year, so it seams that DTG isn't planning to fix them.I find it very strange that they keep pushing out new DLC when the DLC included in the base game still has problems like this. It almost seems they want to discourage new players from buying more DLC.

EDIT: I would like to point out that the workshop contains fixed versions of some of the scenario's
In conclusion I would say that you should only buy this game when it's on sale and you really like to drive trains. Also make sure to read about DLC before buying, because some of it is just not good quality.

EDIT2 (december 2015): It seems like a long-standing scenario bug (801 at 8:01) has been fixed. If they keep fixing old issues, I might even have to change my review to positive. (still not there though)

reviewText:
There is nothing more satisfying than hammering a Bulleid Q1 on the front of 350 tons up the 1 in 40 of Worsborough Incline unassisted.

If you want to get the best out of this game, then you really have to drive the add-on steam locomotives that have the most complex mode of control i.e. live and exhaust injectors with separate water and steam c___s (correct term is censored by Steam - rhymes with 'box'), continuous vacuum brakes with large and small ejectors, cylinder c___s that take account of condensation, front and rear dampers, realistic delays in steam chest pressure when opening the regulator, wheelslip arrestable with sand -

If a) you understand any of that, then you know why I'm giving this a thumbs up.

If b) the above is just noise, then I highly recommend reading up on how to drive steam locomotives, then buying a steam locomotive add-on that lists 'advanced' controls amongst its features. I've tried driving diesel and electric locomotives, and whilst the sounds, graphics and scenery are very atmospheric, the controls are just too simple to make it a satisfying experience, which I suspect is why a lot of people have given it a thumbs down.

For steam loco nuts reading this: the algorithms governing steam usage and generation sometimes seem a bit weird, resulting in impossible levels of performance sometimes. But in the best add-ons, all the controls work in the correct senses, and it's possible to drive in the correct style: wide open regulator, controlling speed with cutoff, managing the conflicting demands of steam chest pressure and injectors, building up and running down the fire according to anticipated demand.

You really do get a proper sense of all the different supplies and demands that have to be managed, from coal to fire to steam to cylinder, from tender to injector to boiler, without doing anything dangerous like allowing a lead plug to fuse, blowing the front off the cylinders with condensation at starting, or getting a blowback in a tunnel.

Considering I only spent a fiver on this, it was a decent game. My first sim and I'm kinda enjoying it so far.
But there's only 3 routes, only a handful of mostly variant based trains (like 5 variations of one diesel loco) and if you want more routes and trains, it's gonna cost you an arm and a leg.
There's no steam trains in the base game, so I'll have to spend more if I want one, like who the ♥♥♥♥ buys a train sim and doesn't wanna drive a steam train?
TL;DR
It's good, but is pulling an EA with all these features that should already be in the game.

reviewText:
A very relaxing and scenic game.  First off, who is this for.  Well, those whom like trains, want a simulator which allows you to relax and if desired, build your own content.   It's definetly not for those whom like to pew pew or want fast paced action.   In it's own world, this does require timing, skill, fore thought.   It's quite nice to ride take the runs through the city or country side with out someone chat spamming you or using explenatives which are not kind.

Here you can explore the world via all modes of rail assets.   This includes steam, diesel & electric engines.  Other variables include what you are moving... freight, people.  Then of course, what part of the world would you like to travel in.  And don't forget the change of seasons as well as time of day.

It is  well supported in the community workshop with a very wide variety to suite about any individual's likings.  There are some extremely brilliant creators which offer very high quality content.   I've found the user group to be most helpful & holding a high level of technical expertise & subject matter.

I have entered several emails to support... all were answered with in 48 hours.

All componets perform perfectly on my pc with highest level of graphics applied.   Yes, there is alot of DLC which can add up $$,   but just wait for the steam sales and chose items which bring you interest.      Additionally, there are some good 3rd party sites which provide quite a bit of content.

Cons... Again to mention the price of DLC content... but on sale it's okay.   And the point loss for speeding... the penalty is excessively high and at times disheartening... This needs to be adjusted.

Would I buy it again... without hesitation.

reviewText:
Uninstalled it. I used to play this before it was bought by Dovetail. Ever since that has happened the game is less a sim and more a game. Where the goal is to get get points, and give dovetail (since actual devs get very little) money in order to get a train or a route. This has turned from a Sim into a black whole for money.
As an a side I never sunk money into an add-on because I felt the base was really solid. But now that it is owned by dovetail add ons seems to be what they are forcing on you.

Last a side all dovetail games (that is what they are not sims) have a unproffessional intro video, trying to convert the masses into something which used to be a niche product. This is not always a bad thing, until you compromise quality of the game for user simplicity (and UI features).

Off I go to go Fly (x-plane) or Drive (user pick) in a proper sim.

reviewText:
If Train Simulator was an incredibly detailed and accuration simulation of driving trains from around the world then maybe the prices of the addons might be justified.

As it is it's a very light simulation that barely covers the basics (read other comments from train drivers and railway employees). After years of development the core gameplay has hardly changed and the graphics have been dragged into the modern era. Nothing about the core product indicates to me that it's made by train enthusiasts but by corporate managers who have found a business model that delivers the least amount of product for the highest dollar they can get away with.

The summer edition is listed at $54 but if you bought the addons individually it would be $339   ... right, OK, makes sense to me.

If you can pick up the base game at a heavy discount then that's a fair deal and you'll get a few hours of enjoyment.  if you pay the requested prices for the addons you're supporting a company that  seems to have no interest in your hobby beyond building OK models and environments.

I keep updating year after year hoping that Dovetail is learning their craft and will really provide an inspiring simulation product but at this point they've demonstrated they do not have the abiility and/or interest.  Rail fans really should be purchasing and supporting another company who is as enthusitic about their passion and wish to provide a full simulation rather than a fairly simple game.

reviewText:
As someone who has played Trainz for years, I wanted to see how this game is compared to it. I got the steam edition during the steam sale and I must say that I feel like the sale price is still too high. The game is visualy pleasing and the routs are really nice but there is a huge lack of trains and routs compared to trainz. And the price for the dlc is just absurd. If you're looking for a train game that has a lot of content in the base game then wait for trainz a new era to be released on steam.

Short version:

Pros:
Nice visuals
rout layouts are nice

Cons:
sever lack of content
overpriced dlc

reviewText: I've played quite a bit of this game, and picked up quite a bit of DLC. The core game, Railworks/Train Simulator has not experienced a significant upgrade to it's core foundation (graphics, functionality, engine optimization) in many, many years. My assumption is that Dovetail Games has set this game up to milk customers. I highly doubt we will ever see an optimized, functional version of the game that meets todays expectations. As it stands now, this was a great simulator 4 years ago, today it's not worth your money new.

reviewText: Some simulators are genuinely fun games that both give you an appreciation for whatever it is you're simulating while simulaniously offering rewarding gameplay that is deceptively simple at first but is later revealed to have a high skill ceiling. Others, like Train Simulator, lack any of these qualities and are instead frustrating shovelware titles. Tack on one of the most absurd examples of DLC hell I've ever seen and you have a game that you by no means should purchase.

reviewText: I'd rather leave a mixed review, but my advice is that you shouldn't pay full price for this game or its DLC, wait until it comes out on sale. The DLC tends to be quite glitchy and low quality, considering you could pay £20+ for some of the DLCs. The game itself runs OK, although it does drop frames even when graphics settings are turned down (that's with a GTX 960 2GB card) but that is probably due to my setup.\n\nSo, bottom line is if you have to buy it, wait for the price to come down in a sale. If you do buy it, you'll be downloading DLC within about a week, since there's not very much to play in the base game. If you're considering getting all the DLC, you probably consider spending the money on becoming a real train driver, it would cost about the same!

reviewText:
I love simulators, being able to fly and drive all different types of vehicles from planes to trains on your computer, in complete comfort and without the need to spend absoulutely huge amounts of money to feel some sense of realism is wonderful.
However, Dovetail Games seems to have forgotten about price in the marketing mix. £25 is what a DLC might well be worth to the devs, but it damn well isn't to most of us.
I have spent amounts of money and time with this game and come to the conclusion that it is pretty well made. It is a mostly working game. You get nicely modelled trains with pretty accurate routes, each uniquely made.
I do find though, dovetail games disrespects its role for Rail Fans. Nothing comes close to the detail, but again, nothing comes close to the price.
There are quite a few glitches, bugs and general annoyances with this game which could be easily spent time on and fixed, leading to an improved game and better product instead of churning DLC out at a phenomenal rate. I personally would really like to be able to get my hands on atleast a good chunk of the British Routes as i live in the UK.

I really don't like giving what could be such a promising game for every Rail Fan in this world a negative rating but the handling of this game by those who own it damages the experience that we should be getting.

Is it not possible for Dovetail to just do something and change quite a lot of its greedy ways?
